name: Wolfenstein: The New Order
description: Wolfenstein®: The New Order reignites the series that created the first-person shooter genre. Under development at Machine Games, a studio comprised of a seasoned group of developers recognized for their work creating story-driven games, Wolfenstein offers a deep game narrative packed with action, adventure and first-person combat.

Wolfenstein is such an odd series. The original formed part of the bedrock that first-person shooters are built upon, but then vanished as Doom, Quake, Half-life, and others grew the genre. Instead of becoming a franchise it resurfaces every decade or so, under the guidance of a different studio, to fulfil our Nazi-killing quota for a time. Now we have this generation's Wolfenstein, brought to us by Machine Games, and after blasting my way through it I can only hope it's going to stick around this time.  The New Order follows BJ Blazkowicz, a square-jawed Captain America type, as he assaults a secret Nazi stronghold in 1946. The Reich has an ace up their sleeve in the form of General Deathshead, one of those jack-of-all-mad-scientists that's good at making everything lethal. The game opens with an intense bombing run that works all the basic controls in as part of thrilling stunts, and keeps on going with combat as you hit the beachhead and start mowing down SS. There are giant robots to crush, commanders to assassinate, towers to scale, cannons to fire, and huge firefights to overcome. The battle reaches a fever pitch, the mission goes south, and you suddenly realize that was just the first chapter of a sixteen-chapter game.  Easily the best part of TNO is the incredible depth of gameplay, which is striking considering how straightforward its predecessors were. Every one of the game's chapters is different in some small way, either being more focused on stealth, or giving you a new vehicle, or arranging battles in a unique way, or just having a different pace from the rest of the hectic, brutal adventure. It's especially good about giving you breathers between intense chapters or battles, as well as plenty of opportunities to explore. Each level has dozens of secrets, not the old hump-the-walls kind but permanent health powerups or collectibles or other bonuses hidden away in logical, secluded places.  You're not just shooting and scrounging, either. There's a whole perk system that runs parallel to the game that rewards you for completing certain tasks, like getting X headshots with a specific weapon or Y kills with explosives. There are four categories of perks that are roughly divided by playstyle, so players who prefer stealth or going Rambo will accumulate perks to help them do so more effectively sooner. It's a good way to get you to change up your style, too, because TNO has so many options when it comes to fighting that you might forget some exist.  That's not an exaggeration, either. You'll find maybe half a dozen guns in the game but each one has dual wielding and a robust secondary fire mode, which can turn your assault rifle from a mid-range sniping tool to a room-clearing double rocket launcher. There's also melee combat and silent takedowns, combat slides that let you keep shooting John Woo style, a seamless cover system, and more. And none of these systems are superfluous because your enemies can be just as varied. Certain weapon types are more effective against armored targets, and the more difficult enemies might have weak points or certain sequences to defeating them.  All of this is built on a game with a strong vein of reverence for its origins, with health pickups that can overcharge you to 300+ and an endless stream of helmets you can slap on for 5 armor apiece. The base movespeed is refreshingly high, letting you run and gun as you please, or snoop around and scramble Nazi brains with your knife. It's a vicious, brutal game with dismemberment and melee kills, and plenty of terrible things will happen to the many characters you meet as well. Here the game walks a fine, featuring a story with strong emotional beats and some very grim overtones, and then has you cracking wise about killing Nazis or shoving them into toilets. It works for me, with the lighter parts almost a coping mechanism for the overarching despair, but I could see it feeling whiplashy for others.  As if that wasn't enough, The New Order is a jaw-droppingly beautiful game. Characters are rendered in cinematic detail, your weapons are hefty and bold, the scenery is meticulously crafted for both incredible vistas and personal touches, and the action is animated with expert skill. The sound design is masterful as well (especially the soundtrack, my God) and you will feel every explosion and impact as you kill your way to the incredibly finale. Your journey will take you to a dizzying variety of locales to show all of this off, including just about every secret Nazi stronghold you can imagine, each rendered and polished in its own unique style.  One playthrough should take you 10-12 hours but there's an interesting choice in the first chapter that splits the game into two timelines, each with small differences to paths taken and story beats. You can also sink plenty of time into unlocking all the perks and turning up all the collectibles if you're the completionist type. Or you can just keep killing Nazis, because Wolfenstein: The New Order makes it an exquisite pleasure. This is easily one of the top FPSes of this generation, and no matter your style of play or taste in game you owe it to yourself to give it a try.

After a 5 year absence, B.J. Blazkowicz is back in Wolfenstien: The New Order, the first title from Swedish Devs - Machine Games.  Set in alternate reality 1960s Europe, Nazi Germany has won the 2nd World War, the Allied nations are in ruins and all resistance has been crushed. Or so it seems.  Mixing surrealistic humour with dark themes, WTNO treads a fine line between serious and kitsch. I personally found the story entertaining, even though plot holes abound.  Along your journey to save the world, you'll be fighting hordes of Nazi stormtroopers and robots (robo-dogs included) in open levels that are pretty unique and well desgined. (don't be put off by the 1st level's linearity, it gets better, trust me.)  Gunplay is excellent. Guns sound powerful and bullets have real impact. Enemy a.i. seems decent (played on medium diff)  Sound design is great as well, with support for up to 7.1 surround sound. Did I mention that the soundtrack is great? No? Well, it's freakin' awesome :)  Graphics aren't the best even @ high settings due to the crappy id5 engine used. However, in certain areas, the visuals look pretty damn good.  The story does drag about 3/4 to the end, but I found the ending worth pushing through it. (My 1st playthrough lasted around 15 hours give or take.)  There is no MP component, which may be a pro/con depending on your personal preference, so bear that in mind.  tldr: Highly recommended, best SP shooter I've played in quite a while.
Was expecting a mindless shooter with no story...  I was extremely wrong.   Buy it. You won't regret it.

Like a coffee gone cold, it's been easy to forget the golden age of the World War II FPS. Albeit edible, any thirsty developer approaches hesitant to the long-gone steam clouds of its hour of freshness. Back before the famed Call of Duty franchise strapped players into the combat boots of the WWII genre, the influential, genre-defining Wolfenstein 3D plotted willing adventurers into the labyrinths of a Nazi prison, with chances of survival as slim as the knife you begin with. Fictictious war hero B.J. Blazkowicz has since become a legendary icon in the realm of interactive media. It's 2014, and MachineGames has not feebly waltzed, but boldly marched back into the dated franchise, armed with a morbid, yet brilliant new concept with Wolfenstein: The New Order.  The war is over, the Nazis have won, and the future of humanity is bleak, all in exchange for Aryan supremacy. People are dying left and right under the non-chalant smiles of Nazi officers. Rudely awoken after a fourteen-year hiatus in an insane asylum, it's an understatement to say that William Blazcowicz has returned with all the bang for your buck, and then some. It's a setup that drains the hope of the world from even the optimistically devout. Depending on your gameplay preference, you may be hesitant to drop the $60 without multiplayer, but fret not. Even as a single-player exclusive experience, The New Order shines at its pacing and the satisfaction that bleeds from the gratuitous violence on the screen and cakes onto the player.  I didn't initially anticipate myself using the game's new, excessively versatile dual-wielding system, but in no time, I grew used to how surprisingly satisfying it clicked with my input. It drifts away from extreme realism and has you off of the training wheels and behind two assault rifles within minutes of play. It's like Skyrim, with, well...never mind.  Also new to Wolfenstein is a perk system, which, like its namesake, paves the way for new abilities, or 'perks' throughout the riveting campaign. While the small touches in combat are welcome, stealth leaves a lot to be desired. It's satisfying, but I believe a lot more can be done with the mechanic, especially since every stealth-related perk is a trivial achievement that involves actions you may have performed already, thus unlocked or imminently such.  Wolfenstein: The New Order will approximately clock you around 10-15 hours, or just under that if you rush. No matter how fast you complete this critter, it will definitely leave you hungry like the Wolf for more.

Wolfenstein – The New Order is the latest instalment of the Wolfenstein Franchise. I have been playing the Wolfenstein games since the Wolfenstein 3D era. Someone who liked the previous games and the game style will absolutely love this new game.  Story: As always you play 'B.J.' Blazkowicz but this time the story is set in an alternate reality. It’s 1960 and the Nazi’s won the war. The story of this game is well written and well-acted.  Game: The game is only single player, there is no multi player. But that’s a good thing so the developers good focus all their attention to the single player game. Unlike a lot of games these days where single player is neglected. It’s a fast action fps in true Wolfenstein style. Graphics and sound are impressive; it’s based on the id-tech engine (like Rage). The story unfolds via in engine cut scene’s. It’s impressive how much detail they put in the story telling. The game can graphically be tweaked a lot, there are a of options that can influence you’re fps. So it’s important to read some of the guides if you have trouble running it. I can confirm it also runs on ultra-wide screens 21:9 aspect ratio and a resolution of 2560*1080 without problems. For those who have never played the original Wolfenstein 3D – the game that started the fps-genre – level 1 is hidden somewhere in the game.  This is a must for everyone’s game collection! Highly recommended!

What makes New Order a great entry in the Wolfenstein series is that it takes place in 1960. Blazkowicz is in a coma following a battle in 1946 and wakes up only 14 years later in an asylum and - to his surprise - notices that WW 2 ended with German victory. He sets out to find the remaining members of the resistance (people he may know from the '40s) and to unite them against an even more dangerous villain.  This setting is great; also, the prologue telling the events of 1946 is also pretty long. This time the occultism-obsessed Reich is replaced with soldiers having a lot of armor and many mechanised units such as the Panzerhund or the Stomper which is the Wolfenstein version of the AT and T from Star Wars.   Graphics-wise the game is pretty as usual thanks to the 5th iteration of the id tech engine which debuted back in 2011 in Rage. This means relatively high system requirements and 50 gigs empty space is a must. Gameplay-wise we are back to a linear shooter where you shoot first and ask questions later. Combat is fast-paced and the option to dual-wield weapons is pretty great!  Stealth gameplay is implemented, too. Sections often have a patrolling commanding officer; you know this as the game puts their signal (i.e. distance) in the upper-right corner of the screen. Here a silent approach is recommended otherwise reinforcements will keep arriving until you deal with the commander.   Regardless of which gameplay method you prefer the game gives you perks. Using all weapons and all methods you can get these that either mean you can carry more ammunition or you have better health regeneration. Beside the story-related achievements most are connected to these. As for achievements: it wouldn't be a Wolfenstein game without secrets. You collect golden items (medallions, chalices, swords etc.), health or armor upgrades, letters and enigma codes that you can open from the main menu.  Characters Blazkowich meet are great companions. In fact, at the beginning of the game you make a decision as to who to save from two of your comrades. A 2nd playthrough is a must if you'd like to see the timeline with the other comrade; interestingly, depending on who you save you complete a different minigame for opening locks (you either hotwire panels or carry out lockpicking). You often return to the hideout between missions to converse with the others and throughout the game you can find several newspaper cuttings elaborating on the events of 1946-1960.  New Order is a great shooter with a relatively long (10+ hours) campaign, great characters and an amazing story. Machine Games did a great job by picking up a classic and giving it a new, interesting story. The many cutscenes and the great characters were the items I primarily missed from Rage; Wolfenstein, however, delivers in all areas.
Best FPS experience (meaning story, gameplay and production values) since Bioshock.

Wolfenstein: The New Order is a great addition to the Wolfenstein series. After a long sprint of mediocre games, Wolfenstein triumphantly returns with an excellent story-driven arcade FPS. It tends to feel a lot like playing a Bioshock game, which isn't a bad thing. With its' divergent storyline, Wolfenstein has managed to capture my attention. Fans of would-be history games will love this.   Story  It is the 1960s and the Nazis have controlled the world for quite some time now. B.J. Blazkowicz, the protagonist of the series, awakes after a head injury to find that the United States no longer exists and is determined to find a resistance. Once he does, the Resistance, led by a charasmatic woman named Caroline Becker, embarks on a quest to take down the Nazi empire from the inside.   Pros:  - An incredible storyline set in a 1960s Nazi ruled world. - Aestheticaly pleasing :] - Mixed loud and stealth play - Great divergent-style weapons; Weapons that could have been. - Great mix of enemy personel.   Cons:  - A break from the traditonal Wolfenstein games (Which isn't such a bad thing) - Protagonist's voice acting can be a bit annoying (constantly whipsering soliloquies in a Christian Bale Batman way)   Verdict?    7.5/10  - Wolfenstein: The New Order is a very fun game. When it comes down to the wire though, it is still simply another arcade FPS along the lines of Bioshock, Serious Sams, etc. The saving grace of this game is the great story. The action is also quite fun. The weaponary you will use in The New Order are divergent designs of real weaponry from the WW2 period. Overall, I enjoy playing this game and the replay value is on the higher side of the scale. If you love killing Nazis, WWII history, or even just Wolfenstein in general, I recommend!

Just Simply Beautiful!  Wolfenstein: The New Order is set in a Nazi controlled world, where the Nazis won World War 2 and now have power over the world. The campaign tells a fantastic story, one of the best I have ever played, where you feel as if you get to know the characters in a mutual way. The gripping story is fantastic with many different items to collect and is all good, but once you have finished the campaign, that's it you have finished. There is nothing else to do when you complete the campaign and is most certainly not worth £34.99 (approx $59.99) due to there being nothing else to do once the campaign is complete.  In some missions, the game gives you the choice of either going in guns blazing or playing stealthily which both have their pros and cons depending on how you want to do it. This gives the player some freedom and I personally find this very good as you choose how you want to play the game. The gunplay is also responsive and fluid but I found that the gun models were a bit big and took up most of the space on the screen, but I wouldn't let this put you off.  I was running this game with these specs:  AMD FX-4300 @ 3.8GHz 8GB RAM AMD R7 250 DDR3 2GB OC  The frame rate was relatively stable with only some lag on huge explosions, but the frame rate is stable 99% of the time. However, whilst I was playing the game in some missions I found that it took a little while to render some textures when I moved the camera and this was frequent throughout the game and bugged the hell out of me!  In conclusion, I think that anyone who loves fighting Nazis and who loves First Person Shooters with a gripping and compelling storyline will adore Wolfenstein: The New Order. I think that Wolfenstein: The New Order deserves an 8/10 as the storyline is one of the best that I have played, however once the campaign is complete, you won't touch this game for a long time. However, I would wait until the next Steam sale as this game is definately not worth £34.99 ($59.99) for the short hours of gameplay that it has.

A refresing modernification of the series.   In short Wolfenstein: The New Order is story-driven FPS with sneaking and explosive action. The game is set mostly in 1960's Nazi-Europe. I played the game once through, took about 16h on über difficulty. Completed missing achievements in 3h. I have played both Wolfenstein 3D and Return the Castle Wolfenstein, but didn't know about 2009 version of Wolfenstein until after playing this one.   If Doom(2016) is a near-perfect upgrad to 90's shooters, Wolfenstein: The New Order brings the shooters from 99-04 to modern times. If you remember games like  No One Lives forever, Soldier of Fortune, Return the Castle Wolfenstein and Codename Eagle , this is something very similar. Healthpacks and armor from the 90's era are still here, but so are the varying levels, scifi/fantasy settings and somewhat serious tone from the later era. Skill tree is there to remind us that this isn't just a graphics update but a part of an an evolution of a genre.   What W: TNO does right is the core mechanic. In First person shooters the shooting should be fun or atleast enjoyable. That hasn't been the case in quite many games in recent years. Most CoD4 look-a-likes have failed to understand that there should be something of a feedback from shooting people in games. I'm not talking about XP or pop-ups but a feeling that I'm doing something violent to another (virtual)person. So after I had charged through the trenches of the first level with dual wielded assault rifles, I took a long look behind me and saw a bloody mess. Although the gun sounds are somewhat lacking in this game, the effects on enemies made me feel like I was shooting guns, not playing laser tag.   Another thing W:TNO does right is it's skill mechanic. Although the skill mechanic is mostly boosting your existing abilities, it works like a charm and it rewards you for playing in a certain way. Unlike many other games with similar mechanics, you get certain skills for doing certain things. If you sneak, you unlock sneaking perks, and if you use explosive you unlock explosive perks. Progress towards skills is not lost on death, so it is relatively easy to obtain all skills during one playthrough.  The games atmosphere gets also an honorary mention. Although the plot revolves around the goofy idea of Nazi Germany winning world war 2 using robotic dogs, the plot stays dark from start to finish. The story sounds absurd but the game stays true to the idea. The world and it's characters act like it's the most natural thing and there exists only handful of moments where the game implies that this might be ridiculous. So the game isn't making fun of itself but let's the player decide if he takes it seriously or not.   The story relies heavily on charachters and they are very well built. Most of the characthers remain memorable even after just a short introduction. Enemies instill fear with their actions and your friend have their own reasons to keep on the fight. The soundtrack adds to the atmosphere though it isn't exactly true to the timeframe.  There are also some features to critique. The game is easy. I usually pick the medium difficulty with games but in this case I changed to the hardest after 1 hour of playing and found that equal to medium in many other games. I barely had to replay any parts because there was plenty of armor and health around even on hardest difficulties. The intelligence and the amount of enemies is also lacking so the game is easy almost to the finish line. Then again I like the fact that the difficulty only ramps up enemies damage, they mostly die quite easily on harder difficulties too atleast if you aim for the head.  The graphics are decent. The game worked just fine for me and looked good enough, but the inconsistency of graphics affected the experience some what. Forced depth of field, no simple AA-setting and some blurry textures made the game occasionally look unnecessarily ugly. Most levels where colorful and the level design was good enough for most of the time. There has been reported serious performance issues with AMD GPU's and the game has frame-caps so do some research before buying if you think these might affect you.  So it's a fun shooter with a decent storyline. Sure it's not the game of the decade, but well worth the 7 euros it costs these days. If you're not into FPS games, this hasn't got anything radically new in it for you to try it. If you happen to like single player FPS-games, this is a must buy.

THIS is what a first person shooter should be to me.  Wolfenstein: The New Order put Wolfenstein on the map again, with outstanding gameplay, great level design, amazing characters and an overall great experience.  When I embarked on my Nazi-Killing quest, I was having fun right off the bat, the weapons feel great and as I played I unlocked perks for my preffered playstyle, it was a lot fo fun to try and unlock them all, there were also a lot of collectibles to be found, some even unlock special game modes. But as I played on, I was pleasantly surprised by the great deal of story and depth this game has, I was expecting a FPS in the area of Serious Sam and Doom, but what I got was a fun FPS that not only provided me with 30 hours of entertainment, but also with a story that sticks and characters I actually cared about, and most surprisingly   I shed a tear in the end    As strange as it may sound, I feel like this is a more mature shooter, not because it has sex scenes or violence, but because it presents you things like genocide, loss, racism, opression and hate.  These things are not shoved in your face, but it's what drives your small group of resistance, for example; you overhear a conversation bewteen a woman and a nazi officer, the woman wishes to file a report of abnormal behavior about her neighbour's son because she saw him trying on his mother's lipstick.  It's not all super serious-business ofcourse, as Wolfenstein sometimes embraces the ridiculous, like dual-weilding Sniper/Laser rifles, drowning nazis in toilets. After an hour or so, the only thing I was still sceptical about was the level variety, but it turned out this is something the game does really well too, you travel all over the world   even off-world, to the moon  , each level feels unique and memorable.  If you enjoy a good shooter that doesn't hold your hand and has a great deal of fun with some depth to it, Wolfenstein: The New Order is just what you're looking for, I know I certainly was.

I see dead Nazis. Everywhere. You shoot them with pistol, assault rifle, shotgun, sniper rifle as well as their future version. You can dual wield too!   The game is a nice mix of oldschool gameplay and modern approach to shooters (pretty unique health system). It offers two timelines (it depends on choice early in the game) - there isn't a big difference between two, but sometimes levels play a bit different. Dialogues slightly change, but the story is the same. Voice acting is excellent and the main hero (voiced by Brian Bloom - Kane in Kane and Lynch games and Jackie in Darkness II) is a perfect match. Other characters are doing very well at least. Story is good, not outstanding but solid. Maps are long, but since it is a linear shooter it doesn't hurt. They allow freedom to a degree. What surprised me - this game has a simple but very satysfying stealth system. Stealthing was very enjoyable and I devoted a full playthrough to it.   Guns are great. They sound absolutely massive (assault rifles in particular). Their models and animations are excellent. Enemy variety isn't big, but every character is detailed and has great animations. They sound very well too.   Collectibles - YES! It wouldn't be a proper Wolf game without those. They are nicely hidden and there is sort of meta game related to them and Nazi Commanders. You have to find out yourself, but this is a really nice idea and I loved it.  Graphics - great. Graphical style - outstanding and certain vistas are stunning - not that they are beautiful, but impressive. Music is great - a mix of metal and industrial - excellent match to atmosphere. Performance is good.   PC version has FOV slider as well as toggle option for crouching, running and iron sights. Everything else that should be in PC game is present. Very good port.   By now you should have an impression that new Wolf is a good game. It isn't. It's excellent in every department. If you like eliminating Nazis then it's a game for you. A worthy RTCW and Wolfenstein (from 2009) successor. Dual wield and wipe them out for good.

The best single-player FPS campaign of the last few years. While others may claim that DOOM 2016 is better, it doesn't hold a candle to Wolfenstein's story which was surprizingly brilliant. The guys over at MachineGames managed to transform the oldest FPS protagonist into a relatable person who is plain-out exhausted over killing hundreds of Nazis. That's just the story, the gameplay is pure FPS action. You can dual-wield almost every weapon in the game (including assault rifles), and it's just   so satisfying   to shoot your guns. Seriously, it can't be described, just play it. I haven't even mentioned the stealth mechanics either, which are very well-developed and you can tell that it wasn't a last-day effort. If you just want an FPS game where the shooting is what matters, then Wolfenstein is one of the best options.   BTW, I got this game dirt-cheap for $10 during a sale, you won't regret it.

After killing Nazis with lasers, killing Nazis on the moon, killing Nazis underwater, killing Nazi armored robot dogs, and killing Nazis with secret stealth Jew helicopters for a couple dozen hours . . . the thing that broke my suspension of disbelief was the game trying to have me believe that NAZIS, of all people, would somehow carelessly leave so many grate and duct covers open or askew in their Nazi bases for me to sneak through.

I was expecting to kick some Nazi butt. This expectation was fulfilled. I was expecting to use really awesome guns to do so. This too was fulfilled. I was not, however, expecting to have my heart broken in two about twenty times throughout the game. Yet, this is exactly what happened. The gameplay rocks, the replayability is great (I've just put in 20 hours to complete my first go through, yet now I have another timeline to experience and up to four different game modes to challenge me), and the story is so enthralling, you actually become William J. Blazkowicz. You feel his joy, his pain, his anger and his sorrow.  Get psyched.

One of the reasons I bought Wolfenstein: The New Order was the astonishing rate of positive reviews. But were they true?  HELL YES! I enjoyed the game from the first moment to the last, the plot is really well written, and even a person who haven't played its predecessors will quickly find himself in the world of Wolfenstein. Playability of this game is through the roof - you can almost feel the joy of killing every damn Nazi (maybe I'm just a sick person). Graphical side of the game is generally satisfying.   The controls are very responsive and after a few hours of play you already feel like an MLG pro. Perks are cool addition (they are kinda standard in most FPS games) and are not that hard to get. Same goes with achievements, most of which are progress related or simply obtainable by getting a certain perk. The characters are very well designed, e.g. Deatshead makes an impression of a real sick mind, striving for power, and through the cutscenes you can almost see why so many people fear him.  Minor flaw of the entire production is the level of difficulty. Personally I think that the hardest difficulty is relatively easy, and for an experienced player finishing Wolfenstein on UBER is not that big of a challenge. Also I can admit that lower difficulties are designed well to fit the casuals that don't want to challenge themselves, but to enjoy this amazing plot.   Last but not least, let's talk about collectibles. Some of them are quite hard to find, but that only makes finding them more satisfying. Moreover, the Enigma Code puzzles are cool addition to the game, and allow us to unlock bonus game modes.   To summarize - I really enjoyed every minute of the gameplay, and I think the game is worth every penny. I'd recommend it to everyone 10/10  Pros:    Well written plot    Playability    Good character design    Achievements and collectibles    Overal fun of playing  Cons:   Lack of a really challenging difficulty level

What do you get when you flawlessly stitch together core aspects of 90's bullet hell shooters with modern cover-to-cover arcade shooters, and dice in the spice of stealth games? You get Wolfenstein: The New Order.   This game has a little something for everyone; but as a huge fan of bullet hell who also apreciates a good stealth game I found myself having to play it again for the full experience.   You can stealth or shoot your way through most anything. You can shoot your way through taking cover and moving up, ai is decent enough to flank you and attempt to hold you in position. Because the ai is aggressive bullet hell players who are used to running and clearing pathways at a time will feel right at home and not feel like the enemies are just standing around waiting to get taken out. Stealth players should knock the difficulty up on their first playthrough, in some areas the AI has some serious sense of awareness but for the majority of the beginning parts stealth is quite easy. Stealth will be very rewarding if you can actually clear whole areas without setting off alarms.  '♥♥♥♥ power armor.'

A hallmark of classic game design. Wolfenstein: The New Order isnt bogged down by modern game mechanics and can stand as a true successor to the original Wolfenstein 3D. If you love classic shooters like Wolfenstein 3D or Half-Life 2, this is probably for you. The dual-weilding/alt-fire mode of the weapons is incredibly enjoyable, and provides a formidable arsenal against the hoards of mecha-future Nazis you will gleefuly gib, splatter, stab, explode and otherwise maim. Howver, I would level that the lazor weapon is relied on too much by the designers as a kill stick for higher calibre enemies, and as a result your traditional stockpile of arms can feel neglected. The game unlike a majority of other moder shooters does not include a multiplayer component, but I never felt anything was lost from a lack of it. Rather the resources that would have gone towards the multiplayer were directed into the single-player campaign. Locations varied as castles, U-boats and even moonbases serve to clearly distinguish the levels, much like an old NES game would.The game also features a plethora of collectibles including Nazi gold, code fragments, diary entries and even records parodying music of the 50s and 60s in a New Regime style to great effect.  While the game does have an abundance of cutscenes, they were never too much of a distraction from the general action of the main story, and provided B.J. a sense of characterization and depth usually unseen in the traditional meat-headed guntoter. Machine Games did an excellent job of creating dispicable Nazi heads you would love to plow through hundreds of their subordinates to eliminate. Sadly the chance to deliver such sweet justice by your hand is denied. The supporting cast is similarly developed well enough to gain your alligiance but is not seen as much. This should stand as a crime: the allied cast simply does not get enough screen time or even backstory to fill my desire to know more about them.   Overall Wolfenstein: The New Order comes out as a highly enjoyable FPS romp through a dystopian future-past which will leave your smiling face coated in Nazi blood.

Ah yisss. It's been a long time since I've enjoyed a single player story driven FPS this much. Wolfenstein: The New Order (W:TNO) is somewhat of a return to roots for the venerable franchise. As most people know, the first game, Wolfenstein 3D is the FPS PC game that popularized the genre and is responsible for its continued success today. After a few sequels, an amazing multiplayer game, and a supposedly disappointing reboot in 2009, W:TNO has a lot to prove. Thankfully, W:TNO exceeds expectations and more.  We return to protagonist B.J. Blazkowicz, the seemingly most generic of all generic McWhite guys who gets knocked out in a late WW2 operation to take down series antagonist uber Nazi, Deathshead. He wakes up 14 years later, but the world has changed. The Nazis won. The Beatles are singing in german. Manhattan is a nuclear wasteland. Swastika flags are flown across the world. Instead of a U.S. army, there is nothing but a small insurgency against the world's new masters. This change in narrative is well executed and shows a hopeless group of rebels fighting for little more than a dream of a world that no longer exists. I was genuinely surprised by how seriously this game took itself, but instead of being soapy and melodramatic, it hit some legitimately painful emotional notes. The storyline is dark and dreary, strange in a game that allows you to dual wield automatic shotguns and blast entire rooms of nazis to bits.  It’s strangely refreshing to see a return to the design of older FPSes. W: TNO is released on today’s market full of killstreaks and regenerating health, where an FPS with no multiplayer component is akin to financial suicide. It’s released in a market full of games with moral ambiguity as well as unrestrained jingoism. However, the bad guys in W: TNO have no moral ambiguity. They’re just evil, dastardly Nazis, who have now taken over the world and are spreading their evil deeds like wildfire. Which makes killing them very cathartic. And oh boy, is the gunplay in this game fantastic. You can dual wield most weapons and each gun is “punchy” and full of character. Eventually you’ll get alternate firing modes that adds to the strategy, as you can have a gun in your right hand using one mode and the gun in the other using another. If I have a complaint about the gunplay is that dual wielding is pretty OP. I understand that this game is all about mowing down Nazis without discrimination, but there’s literally no reason to NOT dual wield. Honestly, you don’t really suffer an aiming penalty at all for holding two giant assault rifles, you can still hit a penny from hundreds of yards away. Regardless, busting into a room, strafing the entire area with a hailstorm of bullets, churning up papers, woodwork and blasting into groups of Nazis, throwing blood splatter and body parts everywhere in a violent cacophony is really something quite special. The stealth system works well too, it’s much like Far Cry 3’s sneaky beaky stuff with throwing knives and silenced pistols.  The developers were right in stating that the lack of multiplayer really allowed them to focus on bringing an amazing world to life. This is one of those games where there’s almost too much detail. You can read tons of newspapers clippings hung up the wall, each explaining a snippet of just how the Nazis won the war. They didn't have to model the thompson submachine gun just for the first mission of the game (never seen for the rest of the game), but they did anyway in order to avoid being anachronistic. Every part of the world is meticulously crafted, from the books lined on a Nazis commander’s room to subtle graffiti dotting the Berlin sewers. It’s all extremely pretty and immersive, and it shows by the insanely large install size (~50gb). I had to leave my computer for almost half a week for it to finish. Regardless, this game is a labor of love, and an incredible showcase of how much detail a development team can cram into the environment.   $60 bucks is asking a bit much for a single player experience that lasts about 15 hours, but multiple playthroughs and collectible items are reasons to come back for more. The core shooting and stealth mechanics are enjoyable and never get old. I’d say wait for it to be about 50% off to pick it up, but if you’re an FPS shooter fan, especially if you’re a fan of older FPSes, this is a must have!

On the surface,  Wolfenstein: The New Order  is a game about killing Nazis and in this it most certainly excels, with immensely rewarding and fluid gameplay that rewards specific play styles and thus replay value. Whoever thought it'd be a great idea to dual-wield pretty much every rifle in the game is a genius, as this features some of the best shooting mechanics I've personally experienced. If you wish to play this simply for the bloody and glorious action, then you certainly won't be disappointed.   But more than that,  The New Order  is a FPS about humanity and how we behave in the face of overwhelming adversity. It avoids the pitfalls of the genre that often portray such evils in superficial and one-dimensional ways and suffer from bad writing as a result.    Wolfenstein  is the complete opposite.  When it comes to depicting the horrors of a technologically advanced Nazi regime, Machine Games must be greatly applauded for handling the subject matter with a fine precision. This is predominantly achieved through the remarkable cutscenes and soundtrack. As one of the greats of the shooter genre, the re-incarnation of  Wolfenstein  often feels like a great film and work of art rather than what could be misinterpreted as a brainless shooter, and is a far-cry from the days of  3D  or  Castle Wolfenstein . The extraordinary direction of the cutscenes is reinforced by the top notch score throughout, which really does capture and engross the player. Complementing the fantastic range of weaponry and upgrades, the sound design in general is phenomenal. This is a very intense game in a lot of ways but remains captivating from start to finish. The single-player campaign is remarkable, and well-worth the omission of any multiplayer component.  The Nazis are, of course, the enemy faction but the game also provides significant commentary on the nature of war itself, as well as granting a voice to those often unheard during the conflicts. While certainly focused on a small range of characters, in areas outside of combat even level design provides a fleshed-out and believable world, one that allows for the grand narrative to play out.  As a protagonist, William Joseph 'B.J.' Blazkowicz is fascinating. Seen by his comrades as the walking death machine and embodiment of shock-and-awe tactics, throughout the game he is given remarkable depth and provides poignant insight into the horrors he constantly experiences. He does not shy away from the horrible things he committs but retains his morality without having to personally justify the things he does.  He is the flawed hero of the  Wolfenstein  series and receives his greatest outing yet here.  Deviating to technical comments quickly, I did frequently experience huge issues with texture popping and stuttering; an issue that apparently continues to plague the engine despite my own attempts to tweak or fix them. The stealth system was fairly robust with decent AI, if somewhat simplistic. Another thing to consider is the price, which remains very high for a game that is more than a year old now... but that is a comment for Bethesda/Zenimax games in general. But I've rambled on long enough though, so let's conclude.    Wolfenstein: The New Order  is a landmark for the shooter genre, boasting top-notch gameplay across the board. It is a narrative done right, portraying the unimaginable horrors of totalitarian cleansing in a believable and uncompromising way. Packed full of detail with a superb soundtrack from start to finish, this stylish shooter is unlike any other.  It is not  perfect  but it is thrilling and deeply satisfying, and gaming is all the better for it.

This game is actually better than I'd been led to believe. I came into the game expecting it to be a competent, if fairly brainless shooter. It's more than 'competent' though. In fact - I think it might be one of the best games of the year. Given that the game is an over-the-top, Nazi killing simulator, I was expecting the story to be more of an afterthought. Surprisingly though, the game's alternate history story is compelling and the game does a good job with world building by peppering the levels with optional conversations and newspaper clippings that help make the world seem more alive. I was expecting the story to go for camp humor, but the game takes itself very seriously at times and the quality of the writing is such that it doesn't come off like some 12 year old's idea of what's is dark and gritty.  I also admire the game's design philosophy, as it does a good job of combining the better elements of new-school and old-school FPS design. For example, the game's health system is a hybrid between health pickups and regenerating health. The way it works is that you can only regenerate health in blocks of 20. If you were to start with 100 health and then lose 95, you'd only be able to regenerate up to 20. I like this system a lot, since it alleviates some of the 'die and retry' repetition from older shooters, but still encourages you to keep moving instead of just hiding behind a wall while you wait for your health to recharge.  The levels are well-designed, with lots of large open rooms, secrets and multiple paths. The controls are nice and responsive, and there's a decent selection of weapons with balanced strengths and weaknesses. You can slide into cover, or shoot while sliding. You can also dual-wield almost every single weapon in the game for an increase in rate of fire while sacrificing accuracy. There are situations where you can take out enemies using stealth, or just go in guns blazing. There's also a perk system that levels up organically based on things you do in the game rather than experience (like x number of head shots with the pistol, or stealth kills using throwing knifes).  The game is just... a lot of fun. There isn't any one thing that makes this game stand out when compared to other shooters, but it does many things very well and manages to feel very fresh while not doing anything particularly new. Machine Games did good here. I really hope that we'll see a sequel from them at some point!

It was a more emotional game than I expected and that takes a good shooter to a great one. Do yourself a favor and get this game on a sale, and kill some Nazis....

Having played all Wolfenstein games going back to the original id bombshell of the early 1990's, this particular version takes the game to new heights. The graphics and visual effects are very good and the audio is also excellent. Stealth is a major factor in survival and can be used to eliminate with great success on most of the enemy including the nasty 'Armoured Dogs' that proliferate the game. Don't try this though on any mechanised robotic device as failure will be certain and will set you back somewhat causing you to start again from the last checkpoint. (Albeit not a major problem).  Weapon options although at times limited do not seem to hinder the main character to any great degree as he is able to despatch most opposition with a minimum of fuss. Planning how you go about this is the important thing to consider as opposed to what you have to do to complete the task at hand. Bear in mind also that you need to replenished ammunition and health/armour regularly so take time to look around for possible and usually neccessary pickups, (approach and gather anything that glows for they will most likey be usable items).  You can collect 'Trophies' as well so investigate unusual looking objects and read notices on walls and desks for information (although this can be a little tedious at times when you are trying to get things done).  If you see a bed, have a sleep and you may be surprised at what happens when you do and my opening line will give you a hint as to what to expect!  The game is not open world in as much as you cannot simply move around free to do things as you wish and unlimited exploring is not an option, you go where your mission directs you and that's it!  This leads me to my main dislike, too many cutscenes that slow down gameplay. At times the player (me at least) is left saying 'Not another one, I just want to get on with the game!'   I guess the creators were trying to incorporate the feeling of abject misery (the prison scenes alone will assert to that), but may have allowed that idea to stem the flow effect as in pulling on the reigns which brings you to a grinding halt. This then gives the game a 'Build it up as you go' arrangement where you are completing missions which only help to build a small part of the next objective. For me that scenario can get a little tiresome, I am sure for others it is more than acceptable so it is all about what an individual wants and expects from a game, but these are my views and I accept that.  In conlusion (and now that I have completed the game), I recommend it as on the whole it is very good but for me at times a bit depressing. If that was the aim of the developers then they succeeded, I just felt a bit hobbled! The real action takes place about a third of the way through and from there it takes off and is excellent and should not dissapoint.  Took approx. 15 hrs to go through first time (not bad), but missed many items that I will collect next time through. I would rate this game 7.5/10 and my screenshots will give you an indication of gameplay.  Certainly worth a go, but maybe best to wait for a sale.  Also, a strong suggestion is to play Wolfenstein 'The Old Blood' first....It is a prequal and it does flow on to 'New Order'. Had I done this I would have started New Order with a different mindset and understanding.

Wolfenstein is a good, solid, shooter that was fun and enjoyable to play. It is set mainly in the 1960s where WWII was won by Nazi Germany. You play as a soldier who was badly injured during an assault and has spent the past few years in a vegetable state in a hospital. The game seems to borrow from other games as at times it will feel very familar. In ways it is similar to the early Medal of Honor or the first Call of Duty games where you encounter enemies at a middle distance and they dive and shoot from behind cover. Other times it seems to have been influenced by Dishonored with the stealth sections and animated backstabs. It doesn't quite match those games in terms of execution of the mechanics but they are decent.   Wolfenstein's employs a standard mission and base system where you complete a few missions and head back to your base for a breather. It uses the base as a way of expanding on some of the characters and fill in the back story. There are some interesting, memorable characters in Wolfenstein but unfortunately that makes some of the others seem one dimensional. I feel that maybe with a bit more time, focus and care this game could have been truly great. The story is at times over the top which lends well to the gameplay, however around the midway point there is one to two chapters which are just plain dumb. It stupidly tosses in a 'secret Jewish organisation' into the mix which, gladly, is only touched on for one chapter. Aside from that there are nice touches which help shape the story; such as the main character muttering about distant memories throughout the game.  The level design is very good generally with expansive indoor maps that allow you to do a bit of exploring. As a homge to the early Wolfenstein games there are gold objects and other hidden goodies littered throughout the game. Letters and newspapers are hidden to provide background and as in early 90s shooters enemies drop armour and ammo. The game strangely gets you to press E to collect these pickups which seems a bit odd. Simply running over them would have been a better choose. I actually liked the perk systems in this game as it is not intrusive. You gain perks by just repeating actions such as killing enemies with throwing knives or headshotting guards. There are four bands of perks which cover stealth play, assault play, tactical and demolition. You can purposely pursue them but I found they populated as I played.   It was nice for me to play a game where the movement is fairly quick, guns are snappy, and pack a punch. Dual-weilding chunky shotguns was a good throw back. There is a peek-from-cover move which I rarely used as you can just blast away. Wolf contains a laser cutting weapon which was versitile and upgradable. Again, if more time had been spend on it I feel it could have been as good as the Gravity Gun in HL2. There just aren't too many levels that explore its features fully. It also highlights a few inconsistences with the levels and 'world'. An example would be how certain metal sheets and surfaces are destructable yet some wooden panels or metal boxes aren't. I think it is more a restriction employed for consoles that hindered the game a bit. Its the same with the textures which can be low-res in some places. The game does run very smooth and I experienced no slow down.  The AI of the enemies is a lot better when they are fighting as it quickly becomes apparant that their stealth AI is sloppy. I've had guards look straight at me or see their colleague get shot just to turn and walk away. The first stealthy mission is the best as it has multiple routes the others are very hit and miss. Firefights however are very satisfying and can be challenging when you encounter the different types of soldiers. The game has a decent difficulty level which can cause you to die a few times when you get overwhelmed. Overall Wolfenstein is worth it as it is a fun experience. The majority of the levels are diverse in theme and design. It is not run and gun shooter of old but more of a blend of modern and old. There is no magic directional arrow showing you the way so sometimes you can get lost. I will be replaying this game again to see what I missed. It just misses out on being an 8 out of 10 game.

The downtime between missions is great, and meeting the different people within the resistance is great, it adds a personal feeling to the game, and the easter egg in the resistance headquarters is brilliant!  The soundtrack is brilliant, and you can find collectable records in the game so you can listen to a 60's Nazi take on well known western music of the real world. In each level you play you will unlock concept art of the levels, and a quick screenie will provide you with lots of wallpapers to spuce up your computer. There are so many different collectables that you can find and recieve that add so much depth to the game, and if you're a story lover, then this will definitely take your fancy, so make sure you read the character bios and listen to the audio logs and more!  There are many different ways to play the game, there are four different skill trees, each with unique perks, the trees are; Stealth, Tactical, Demolition and Assault, and by completing certain objectives you can unlock a new perk, and you can have as many as you want, it's not just one tree. By doing this, it adds a new element to the game, which way do you want to play? There are quite a lot of opportunities to go at it stealthily and more opportunities to go at it guns blazing.  As afore mentioned, there are few faults I can pick, the only big noticable thing is the texture pop-in, which has not been improved since the first ID Tech 5 game, RAGE (2011), however, it's likely that you'll be having so much fun that you won't really notice it.  TL;DR This game is definitely worth your money, it's such a fun game, and if you love story focused shooters then you'll love it!

When I saw this game at first I thought something along the lines of 'Looks alright I'll buy it when there's a sale'. So in the autumn 2016 sale I bought it. I finished it the very next day.  Best. In fact as I progressed through the over-the-top steampunk 1960s I connected more and more with the game and the story. The story legitimately suprised my in this sense. As my home is in the multiplayer shooters and the campaigns are more of a 'Oh my internet is down I'll play this'. There are two main stories, which split with decisions you make ingame, which I have played one of. The story that I finished (fergus') was presented with solid script and many moments of genuis, comically or in set peices.  The gameplay as a whole is thoughly intertaining with the loud and brash or stealthy and silent options presented, both giving satifying results and above all else Gore. The gore and horrors this series is famed for, while not shown by throwing bucket-loads of blood, is ever present and satisfying especaily on the antagonists.   Lastly for all the graphic enthusiasts. While this game is not massively intensive to run it still looks georgous.  Overall I would throurghly reccomend this game and encourage you not to overlook it.

Wolfenstein, does anything more need to be said? This is the grandfather of shooters and this iteration brings what it promises. The game provides ample oppurtunities to mow enemies down in various ways, plus where else can you dual wield assualt rifles?  The graphics, many people complain about the textures, pop-in and quality, but honestly the game looks gorgeous. It will have you exploring the world just so you can see all the smaller details developers added in. The gameplay is solid brining what a Wolfenstein needs to bring, guns, guns and even bigger guns.   Now then, the few issues encountered can easily be solved with a patch so its not really game breaking in nature. This is one of the few games that upon launch I encountered no game breaking bugs. Which is a fresh experience in its own right.  Is the game worth $60? In my opinion, yes. If you are a Wolfenstein fan then you need to be playing this game. Short: Strongly recommended. Excellent shooter mechanics and surprisingly well written moving story. If you liked Half-life 2 you'll love this game.  Medium: When we write the history of video games as an art form I believe this game will be remembered as a landmark for its treatment of sex. The game boldly makes it clear up front that sex is part of Blazkowicz's relationship with his love interest, yet they manage to do it in a way that elevates it from simple lust or an exploitive attempt to sell sex to a depiction of an intimate experience shared between people who truly love one another.  Long: This game fails to live up to the legacy of previous Wolfenstein games. When I see Wolfenstein in the title of a game I think men with biceps so large they have difficulty wearing anything with longer sleeves than a muscle shirt, chin clefts so deep you could build a mineshaft in them, machismo levels so high that they punch on sight any sissy who actually uses the word 'machismo', and ranges of emotion that lead you to suspect they've undergone a partial lobotomy. To all outward appearances this perfectly describes the protagonist William 'B.J.' Blazkowicz. In previous games Blazkowicz has always been little more than a 1940's Duke Nukem with just barely enough taste not to quote bad movies while killing Nazis. As a result I came into the game expecting 'Generic Nazi Murder Simulator 2014'. That is not what I got.  The story of Wolfenstein: The New Order as any synapses will tell you is the tale of jarhead William 'B.J.' Blazkowicz waking up in an alternate universe in which the Nazi have won WW2 and taken over the world. He has to lead the resistance, tear down their symbols of power, bring hope to an otherwise hopeless and dreary world, yadda yadda yadda something something Half-life 2. This is all true. However the game is in many ways Half-life 2's better in many ways. The writing is shockingly good. In inner dialogues and exchanges with his companions we occasionally glimpse something deeper and more sensitive through Blazkowicz's solemn and emotionless mask. We begin to see him not as a man who does not feel, but as a man who hides his feelings for fear that they will make him weak and destroy him. At the end of the first mission he (and thus the player) is forced by a villain to make a sort of Sophie's choice, with no third option save for a gameover. It's a horrible and terrifying scene during which we see him at his most vulnerable, and while he doesn't show any visible emotion it clearly leaves mental scars which stay with him for the rest of the game.  It's not just his ability to feel pain the game shows us either. It's his ability to feel love. When we write the history of video games as an art form I believe this game will be remembered as a landmark for its treatment of sex. The game boldly makes it clear up front that sex is part of Blazkowicz's relationship with his love interest, yet they manage to do it in a way that elevates it from simple lust or an exploitive attempt to sell sex to a depiction of an intimate experience shared between people who truly love one another. While she initially appears to be a vulnerable maiden in distress, over the course of the game we begin to see that she is in many ways Blazkowicz's counterpart. Just Blazkowicz conceals sensitive soul inside a warriors body, we learn that she conceals a warriors soul inside her fragile exterior.  The ending is also not what you'd call typical of stereotypical FPS games. I don't want to spoil it because it's actually quite moving. Oh and the FPS bits are quite nice too.

As someone who has played every Wolfenstein game in existence (and yes, that includes the first two Apple ][ offerings), I wasn't sure how this new game would stack up with Raven's 2009 Wofenstein. That game was a wonderful shooter and still, to this day, I'll take any opportunity to say 'Frightened, American?' Well New Order stacks up very well, indeed. No lip service branding here: every bit of this game is evidence of the developers love for the Wolfenstein franchise. The game is a pure shooter for sure - but everything seemes to flow so well within it; the death animations, the gun balance, the play based skill trees, and the cut scenes actually feel to augment the experience. And the experience is nazi killin' fun. The subject matter is [i]dark[/i], though. The game makes you feel what the natural extension of a Nazi victory would mean, and some of that is very unsettling. I'd recommend this game to fans of the franchise or to anyone looking for a story based thrill ride. It certainly delivers. Not pefect for sure (some of the skill trees 'unlocks,' can be a little silly and the AI isn't perfect), but very, very fun. Oh, and, 'Frightened, American?'

This game.. Story is awesome! Graphics are fantastic! The length of the singleplayer campaign is good for a modern day shooter. This game encompasses old and new, a throw back to the health and armor system that seems to have been lost on most shooters these days. The gunplay is absolutely fantastic, it feels smooth and fresh like it did in RAGE but better in my opinion, I haven't felt this satisfied with a shooter since Half-Life 2: Episode 2. The sounds and music transitions with the cut scenes are absolutely beautiful and the voice acting is really well done.   With hints of Tarantino style story telling, the game pulls you through both sides of the spectrum when it comes to feelings and responses, like a rollercoaster of rage and punishment. I can safely say this is the first time a game has really put me through a process of 'Oh god that is awful, why am I looking at this' to 'I really want to rip that persons head off' It's a game that, to many, doesn't seem to take itself seriously, but it does - in its own special way. It's a hard thing to go into an alternate path of history and for it to be taken seriously. While Wolfenstein The New Order may miss it at some points, it nails it to a cross on a frequent basis. While I was playing I constantly was thinking about the story and how it seemed to be an analogy of insanity & rage. The level of absurdity you go through was extremely satisfying, you get the feeling that its completely ok to go over the top to wipe a Nazi out, that you could not accept that they became such a power and you would do everything to wipe them out with no remorse.   I'm currently going through the second playthrough at the moment. There is a point early on in the game where you make a choice and it ends up giving you a specific experience with characters because of that choice. You have altnerate methods of accessing locked areas, and new secret areas that you will come across, as well as acquiring weapons at earlier points in the game, all depending on the choice you make early on. It's an interesting twist to the game, and definitely can make a second playthrough worth it to some extent - may update when im finished with the second playthrough.   Overall Wolfenstein The New Order didn't play the usual harp strings of emotion, it took its own path - while this path may not fit for some, I have a feeling many will really get a kick out of it, and find it extremely satisfying. I wish there was more to play, I really hope MachineGames continues to dig into the Wolf universe, this is the first Wolfenstein single player experience that I REALLY loved, even over RTCW (with the exception of its multiplayer ;p)   also MachineGames, if you're listening - get on the phone with Splash Damage and work with them on making Enemy Territory in this universe ;)  -- I know many people are having issues with playing the game from a technical standpoint so if they are curious, I played the game with maxed out settings @ 1600x900 resolution and things ran smooth as silk for me, didnt even crash once, I was even live streaming the whole thing.   System Specs:  Intel 'Haswell' Core i5 4670k  8GB Corsair Vengeance DDR3 GeForce GTX 750ti 2GB OS Drive: 128GB SSD  HD (where steam is installed): WD 500GB Sata 3.0

Ahh.. The New Order.. After the success which was the Return To Castle Wolfenstein, fans were waiting 8 years for another Wolfenstein, which turned out to be good, which was it's biggest issue. It was just 'good', a decent FPS shooter, but without the feeling and climat of the 2001's RTCW. 5 years after, in 2014 we got Wolfenstein: The New Order. Bethesda, Machine Games and id, promised, that the new Wolf, will stand up to the level of it's 13-year old brother. But is it actually worth to be called 'RTCW's heir'?  HOLY F*CKING YES! Where should I start? The plot. The beginning takes place during WWII, which should not be a surprise to anyone. Like in previous games, you play as a B.J. Blazkowicz, once again with a goal to finally kill 'Deathshead' Unfortunately the assault on his fortress ends up with a failure, you lose your squad and find out that 20 years passed by and nazis has taken the control over the world! It is your job to at least try, to do something about it, if it's still possible that is.  During the game, you'll visit various places, even the concentration camp in which you can experience the particle of suffering from people that are held there. You can hear them talking about their families, how they got seperated from each other, etc. In RTCW you had castles, secret laboratories, catacombs, etc. and if you actually thought you saw everything, and it can't go further than that, then bruh... you haven't seen anything yet.  The game looks and plays great, even on my crappy PC, with the lowest details it looked really good and still gave me a lot of fun.  When it comes to music, it's really good, but to me, there's only one track that truly stands out. Unfortunatelly it plays once and very late into the game, but when it plays, man.... Chills all the way down the spine. You did a great job with it, Mr. Gordon. Hats off.  Someties you get to choose the way of killing the nazis, that is when the 'signal detected' message appers in the upper-right corner. It means that there are commanders around which can call for support if they find you, you can eliminate them one-by-one and be sneaky-peaky, or just say BRING IT ♥♥♥♥♥! Rush forward and vaporize everything that breathes. Personally, I recommend the first way in later stages, especially on higher difficulty settings. Overall when it comes to gameplay there's nothing wrong about it and your weapons can be upgraded too (f.e. your assault rifle can shoot rockets!).  But of course there always have to be some flaws, here's no exception. It took me 15 hours to beat the game on 'Bring em' on' difficulty, which seems preety short to me, also some of the later stages follow the similar scheme. Kill nazis in a big hall or something like that, move through corridors and tunnels, kill nazis, move through tunnels and repeat till the end. The game also lacks bosses, there are 3, maybe 4 in total, which wouldn't be bad, RTCW had the similar amount of bosses, but here, they all appear near the end! I almost started thinking that there may be no bosses at all! Who doesn't like to take down the giant mecha and make some noise from time to time? The worst thing about this game is the ending, the motherf**king ending which just begs to be different, and i don't understand why it ends in such a way, it could easily be different, why they decided to put out something like this, I have no god damn idea...  *SPOILER WARNING* If you haven't beaten the 15th chapter - don't uncover the text below!    There's one moment in the game, that I remember the most, earlier in this review I mentioned, that one song stands out of the entire OST. It plays in 15th chapter, it's so beautiful and fits SO PERFECTLY, that i don't know how to describe it. It fills you with sorrow and anger that can be satisfied only when all the nazis in your sight will bite the dust, as you walk through the burning remnants of your destroyed past-HQ, knowing that your friends are dead or captured by Deathshead... I have to say, that this might be the first time, when I got touched while playing a video game. And it comes from a guy who gave no sh*t about the ending of 'Angel Beats'. Anyway, the song is called 'Ransacked'.    To sum up, I'd love to give this game 10/10, but I can't, instead I have to give it 9/10 because of the flaws I've mentioned above and the price this game's asking for. 50 Euro is too much in my opinion, so just wait for the discout and then pick it, you won't regret it. I f*cking recommend this game to everyone, despite some flaws it's still an amazing game that will blow your balls, or boobs. And I can see why TB picked it as 'The game of 2014.'

Ok first thing’s first, this is NOT a remake, it’s not even a reimagining, this game appears to happen roughly in the same universe as the original Woflenstine but it is it’s own game.  Visually it is a vast improvement over iD’s last title Rage though they appear to be using an updated version of the same engine. You will see some Unreal engine style texture pop-ins, which is a shame in this day and age, however it runs very well and for what it is the game still looks good and has some very nice visuals. Levels have some level of destruction; at least of cover so there is that upgrade, pillars, barriers, certain types of metal sheets can all be gradually broken and shot through different methods. There is a minor cover system, akin to FarCry 3’s system where you can pop out or over something if you get into the correct position which helps during combat. There are modeled and skinned in damage indicators for enemy troops, and given that this is a iD game expect some gibs, limbs, some pretty brutal cut scenes, and fair quick but significant take down animations some are quite visceral.  There is a stealth mechanic and depending on your play style you may simply favor running and gunning which, given the fact that you can dual wield almost every weapon in the game you have enough firepower in your hands. However if you wish to avoid as much attention and fighting as possible, or you enjoy watching the stealth kill animations then you can, at times it’s more beneficial to do so as a fair amount of the enemies in W:NO pixel hunt or are just extremely accurate even while running or moving around. However stealth wise they tend to be both blind or severely impaired, while at the same time incredibly hyper sensitive to anything and unfortunately the cause varies, the stealth over all can be very forgiving, which is good because there is NO QUICK SAVE! That is unfortunately correct, there is no quick save in this PC game, I do not understand why this was not added in but the actual developers Machinehead Games really screwed up with this omission. If you die part of the way through an engagement you will probably not be able to start where you’d like and sometimes you have to do entire sections over again, other times the auto save places a spot right after. You will need to learn from your mistakes or trial and error it unfortunately; however there are only a few sections in the entire game where I can honestly say that I had trouble with.   There is a leveling up/skill tree system for this game and for the most part it flows quite well. There are requirements that you have to meet in order to move onto the next branch or in order to meet a requirement for a skill that is not actually connected to a previous skill. These vary from performing take downs, throwing back grenades, killing a certain amount of enemies while dual wielding weapons, silent kills with throwing knives, and so on. Some of the requirements however are for the most part nothing but grinding and putting yourself into situation that you would normally not put yourself into AND the game very rarely actually uses this kind of attack which defeats the purpose of requiring it, so you will have to find work around for these unfortunately. Luckily the forums on Steam are fairly helpful and I know of two skill points that I didn’t know if I would be able to do them that I was actually able to pull off fairly easily by cheating the system, but not actually cheating mind you, simply the description on many of them is vague and the requirements can be met in different ways then what is actually written in the game.  One other major fault is the totally not old school mechanic of having to manually pick up items one by one. Picture this, you’ve expended your assault rifle ammo and you’re in a semi arena still rife with bad guys, well in W:NO you need to crack open boxes and constantly be looking at the floor for dead bodies so you can rapidly press your use key in order to pick things up. I can not understand what they were trying to do with this; I can maybe understand it for the gold items, intel and other collectables but NOT armor, health and ammo. This gets worse when you have to fight the last boss, since every enemy in the game has pin point accuracy you have to continually run and “dodge” in order to juke his shots and on top of that you need to scramble around looking for health, ammo and armor pick ups in boxes and frantically press your use key in order to pick them up. I have to wonder if Bethesda had anything to do with this choise since, as I recall, you picked up items manually in many of their games; the difference being however that unlike say Oblivion you are not dodging bullets in frantic fights.  The story and characters are pretty well done and there is a single point where you make one decision that will alter what doors you can interact with and that is all, there are no alternative story arcs. This is fine because the story is fairly good, at least when compared to past Woflenstine titles, the characters and B.J. are the main focus of most cutscenes as well as minor story additions when you are back at the main base. B.J. is far more fleshed out in this version of him then in any of the past games, while he may seem to be just a muscle head they make him out to be fairly intelligent and kind. Each side character has their own story line and you will get bits and pieces of it as the game progresses which is a welcome addition as it further fleshes out that person. While nothing ground breaking happens during these lulls in the fighting it’s defiantly a welcome addition.   The weapons feel and sound quite good and the skill upgrades add some flavors to them that help in dealing with some of the more heavily armored enemies. Though speaking of enemies some of the armored human units like the shotgunners are just damn annoying and practically a mini boss, their shotguns ricochet off surfaces and do insane amounts of damage in a short amount of time. There is usually one extra attachment for each weapon, though one in particular has several through the entire game. The real benefit to the skill columns is that you can gain all of them and go back and start a new game, getting the benefits which will enable you to play with a different playstyle then you would have before.  Both the sound effects and the music are very fitting for the game type, the weapon sounds are very good and have a plenty of oomph behind them, the shotgun being one of my favorites, it sounds like the part. The music was actually better then I expected, and it changes from stealth to active engagement when stealth is broken. Each level has its own music score and they all sound very different from each other, sort of giving them even more of their own personality.   Being a Wolfenstine game the developers saw fit to go back to the roots and added a fair amount of collectables, gold items, intel, music, letters and audio logs. If you’re a completionist then you will get some extra hours trying to fine every single item, which for me added to about 36 hours total play time. Granted this game is only single player thus some people may say it’s not nearly enough content given how large the game really is, 40 gigs is never something to sneeze at. There is some talk about adding a few extra levels, maybe multiplayer or something; however it is all just hearsay.   For $60 full price I might be hard pressed to suggest a game like this, however given that it did give me 36 hours, it’s not a hard sell I would say however that if you are at all on the fence about the price versus the content then I would wait for a sale, after that it will be well worth it. Either way I had fun with it and I hope they will continue in some way, this also gives me some hope as to what Doom could possibly be like.

Wolfenstein: The New Order's shooting mechanics are sublime. The audio and visual feedback, along with the excellent animations and diverse enemy types all work in concert to provide a joyful shooter romp. And all this is made sweeter by the surprisingly fresh story. Whereas antiheroes and muddled morality systems seem all the rage in today's pop culture, WTNO returns to a simpler time, in which heroes are heroes and villains are horrible, evil ♥♥♥♥♥♥ whom I wanted nothing more than to see put six feet under the ground. The problem of ludonarrative dissonance (as seen in recent shooters such as Bioshock: Infinite) is not a problem here, because the player experiences firsthand, often in states of powerlessness, the atrocities committed by the bad guys, so often that by the time he or she is locked and loaded with akimbo, fully automatic shotguns, he or she is ready to mete out righteous buckshot justice. More than dull shooting galleries, every fight becomes an act of catharsis. This is why we crave better stories in games - not because of an appeal to some artistic standard set by film and literature, but because of the way it FEELS.   Three-dimmensional characters, wonderfully despicable villains, a romance subplot that, as far as I'm concerned, is touching, and a seemingly meatheaded protagonist who, as you get to know him, turns out to be just a peace-loving country boy fighting for friends, family, and barbeques on sunny, suburban lawns.
If you want a shooter with a good story, I would recommend you this one.
