I hadn't played a Wolfenstein game since Spear of Destiny and was a little curious about the series.  I couldn't help but compare Wolfenstein to Rage and Dishonored. Wolfenstein doesn't have the same out of this world environments that Rage has and it doesn't have the sort of moral choices that make a real difference in the outcome of the game like with Dishonored. Also, the perk system in Wolfenstein seemed more like it was meant to distract the player from how easy most of the game is by giving them a treat each time they stabbed someone just so a certain number of times. The perks really don't translate to adding a new method of playing the game, they give you more ammo, a little bit of health regeneration, occasionally you can dismember enemies, or something else like that. Its not like how different skills can drastically change how you play the game like with Dishonored. Another comparison that came to mind is to the Metro Series whose story line (and the 'moral' choices you must make) interested me more and also had better stealth versus run and gun gameplay styles than Wolfenstein (again imo). I guess overall I felt like Wolfenstein combined a lot of popular game elements I'd seen in other games I liked but didn't do any of them nearly as well.   However, Wolfenstein does have a gripping story that made me care about the characters. I got hit in the feels a few times when **** went down with a main character and the storytelling cutscenes are amazing. It also made me think I was playing a sort of messed up version of Uncharted. The game took me 18 hours to beat which I did in one sitting netting 65% completion. I played in on Uber difficulty for the entire game except the last boss which I had to reduce the difficulty to hurt me plenty for. So I guess despite all the things Wolfenstein wasn't, it's still a solid title that was worth purchasing at 50% off during the steam sale. It definitely passes the 'movie test' (is it as much or more fun than a movie for as much or less than the cost of a movie per hour?). So I have no regrets except that I didn't unlock the explosives perk tree because I stealthed almost the entire god damned game even when I didn't have to.

This is the story in Wolfenstein: The New Order where Germany wins with strange superior weapons somehow made by the games antagonist in this alternate universe.   Gameplay wise Wolfenstein: The New Order doesn't run from its roots or tries hard to be something it isn't. Instead it embraces dual wielding assault rifles, and whatever you can think of would be in a Wolfenstein game is there. There is even the occasional stealth routine you can do, but you're not punished for simply taking out your biggest gun and start killing those evil nazi your way. All the weapons in the game also have their merit isn't thrown in just to be there, but all have their strengths and weaknesses. Despite having such relatively simple gameplay it is done really well, and I was entertained the entire way through this game, which was much longer than I first thought as well. The atmosphere also plays a part in this game, and really brings the world to life with nazi propaganda and presents you with a quite obscene future where nazi ideology rules the world.   If you're looking for a beautiful and fun FPS title Wolfenstein: The New Order should certainly be taken into consideration.

The storyline isn't what shines in Wolfenstein: The New Order. It's...okay, I suppose. It's not groundbreaking but it's not terrible. What really shines is the combat. It retains the classic feel of the original Wolfensteins, in terms of combat strategy (none necessary), combat flow (very fluid), and gun handling (nothing special necessary aside from point at bad guy). Yet it has the current gen polish that smooths out what was rough with the genre from it's inception. You don't need to crutch on one or two guns due to limited ammo. The controls offer more depth to position yourself advantageously. Cover can actually be used, even if it isn't critical if you can hit the A and D keys. And it looks good, both in terms of graphics as well as art style. So buy it. Play it. Love it. I have no doubts about that.

This is the closest thing to a flawless game I have ever played. Each aspect of it is perfectly crafted, whether it's the story, the gameplay, the characters...  Let's start with the story. It is 1960, and the Nazis have won World War II. Everything we know about the free world has gone to hell and been replaced by a horrifying vision of what could have been. Down to the tiniest details, such as a Nazi-style Beatles album, or letters recounting the war, this is a fully fleshed-out world, and each twist and turn of this fast-paced tale hits you hard and makes you feel real emotion for what is happening. The setting and the level designs feel fluent and fitting in this grim reality, as do the look of the soldiers and weapons. There is a ton of background information you can discover about it as you progress through the campaign.  Next, the gameplay. Very much in tune with the original Wolfenstein games of old, The New Order feels like the perfect mix between modern and classic. The health system makes each leap from cover to cover suspensful, as you have to keep finding health packs and hidden rooms to stay alive as the futuristic soldiers fire at you. Also in vein with classic shooters, you have access to every gun you pick up at any time throughout the level. This leaves room for a lot of variety as you mow down evil soldiers. Yet, despite these more retro aspects of gameplay, the shooting and sprinting feels fast and responsive. Not once did I feel like I died because I was too slow, or got stuck. Also, almost every gun you pick up will get upgraded as you progress, adding insane features to your favorite weapon. Now, the one thing that was a little lacking was the stealth. It feels a little like it was added last minute, after they had designed the game to be a fast-paced shooter (which it is), and sometimes it can be annoying. But, it is still possible and very fun to sneak around and silently pick off guard dogs or commanders. In addition, The New Order has a very cool perk system, that unlocks new abilities as you carry out actions or takedowns in-game, and you can progress down a multitude of skill-trees, such as stealth or melee, or shooting to name a few.  Finally, the characters. Good god, the characters. Each one is a shining gem, sticking out uniquely in their own ways. They too, interact with the world around them, and have great dialouge/voice acting behind them. You begin to feel a bond with your friends, and an immense hatred for your ruthless enemies. Every nazi boss or major character is different, and by the end of the game, you will want to kill every last one of them. All of this character development is backed up by secret letters you can collect that talk about the characters, or audio logs that you can unlock. Nobody in this game feels flat, especially not your character, B. J. Blazckowicz. He is not the traditional, remorseless first-person-shooter protagonist at all. He feels regret, or sympathy, or disgust, or hatred. He too interacts with his surroundings and turns an already great game into an excellent experience.  All in all, you should definently play this. It has really changed the way I view first-person-shooters, and I feel like now I've been spoiled by this wonderful game.

This is the Wolfenstein game I think many of us have waited a long time for.   The game has so many strengths going for it: amazing music, fantastic voice actors, dialogue that isn't cheesy, and the reason we play such games; solid enjoyable gun-play. I personally think that their devotion to single-player only is what allowed for such a well rounded experience.   I want to get the 'cons' out of the way, as they are few, and really are more quibbles than anything. The story, at points, feels a little rushed. Could have used a little slower pacing. The shotguns, while pretty devestating, sound and feel a bit underwhelming, especially when compared to the assault rifle. Then again, the Brutal Doom mod has set the personal bar in regards to how shotguns should sound.   I think the game blends very well elements of 'old-school shooters' and the current mechanics of todays. The health system is like that of Far Cry 3's: each health 'chunk' (5 in this case, each worth 20 health) regenerates within its own 'chunk'.   I also like how it brings elements of the old-school in regards to the levels. To survive, you need to find health kits, armor, ammo, and so forth. There's also a lot of hidden goodies to find; secrets, as they used to be called. The levels are well varied and nicely designed.   I could go on with all the various nuances with the game, or how many great homages it pays; especially with the final boss. I can't decide between my two favorite moments: dropping acid with Jimi Hendrix, or finding the mattress to have a nightmare, and have it be Wolfenstein 3D.

Shooters of today are dumbed down and force you along a linear path which feels more like a chore than a game. Wolfenstein The New Order is a call back to when shooters were supposed to be fun and engaging. You can dual wield any gun in the game and the stealth kills are different if you have one knife or two. You carry every gun from the start of the level to the end unlike other shooters with only two weapon swapping. Not only can you backtrack for ammo and health but you can run around looking for collectables and newspaper articles which give you story. You can see how many collectables are in the level and where they can be found on the map, which is a nice touch. The game doesnt hold your hand or bug you every five seconds about the mission and you can run around the level without consequence. The sounds of the game are top notch and should be turned up. The guns in the game have a fair amount of recoil and have the distinct sound of firing a weapon. Everything just feels right when you are firing dual shotguns at your enemy.  The two downsides that i will say arent that great are 1.) The perk system is kind of tacked on and feels cheap but on the bright side if you die (or reload) all of the progress on the perk tree stays with you. So you could grind out perks that you want and you dont have to progress the story if you dont want. 2.) There isnt any saving just checkpoints. On the bright side the checkpoints are very close together so you never lose a half hour of gameplay.  As the story unfolds you get to see what the Nazis were infamous for during WW2. This game shows and tells you a lot of very literal things that are historically accurate even if this game is set in fiction. The portrayal of what the Reich did to people and the fear, pain, and misery they instilled into the world is clearly on display. The times may be different (in game) but the evil things that the Nazis do is nothing new. This game, for me at least, makes me want to be a better person in spite of all the dehumanizing things that happen. It makes me want to help somebody i dont know because its the right thing to do.  There was some setbacks at launch, but as with any new game it will be patched out. The game feels right at home on the PC with no distinguishable console features.  All in all its one of the best run and gun games to come out in a long time. You can see that the game wasnt just another carbon copy of CoD but a game made out of love for the genre. This game may not be the game of the year but it has a lot of heart. The hype and marketing campaign comes with any triple A game and while its not the be all end all of shooters it is a well crafted game that does the Wolfenstein name proud. IMHO this game is worth the money.

Wolfenstein is a competent shooter, with a suprisingly deep narrative. Some of the attempts at creating emotion are a bit too obvious, but the story is well-written. Voice acting is a win as well. The entire game is saturated with a dark, dark atmosphere. You point your gun, enemies die. You sneak around, enemies die. Nothing ground-breaking, but it's notably smooth and makes for an enjoyable gaming experience. To sum up, Wolfenstein is a story-driven military shooter that doesn't quite break new ground all over the place, but is still well above run of the mill.

I will start off by saying this is the best game I have ever played.  I have played other games for longer. I have had more fun and laughed more from other games. But I can say without a doubt this game is the best I've ever played.  Wolfenstein: The New Order is a brilliant game. It's a thrill ride of ups, downs, and killing Nazis. The story is one of the best I've ever seen a game, and it's blend of adrenaline-pumping action with genuine moments of sadness and regret from the characters is very rare in a modern-day FPS. It expresses the true machinelike evil of the Nazis, and people dogged resiatance to them. Even in the darkest moments of the game, someone will always bounce back. Although it' s fictional(duh) and contains some fantasy elemenst (Jewish superweapons, anyone?), the story hits home with every one of us. Although we are thrust into the story just like that, Aas we sneak our way through each level and then inevitbaly screw up, get caught, and bring out the dual-wield laser guns and automatic shotguns, we begin to understand what we are fighting for: freedom, and what we are fighting against: oppresion, imprisonment, gruesome cruelty(this gmae lives up to it's ESRB rating, and not in a good way) and of course, Nazis. The end, although bland, still left me in shock and awe from just everything this game has to offer. There were times when I almost felt like crying(as much as a game can make you cry), and throughout it all it was evident everyone was suffering(including the protaganist). The story is beyond anything else you will likely see in another FPS for a while. It's great.  Gameplay wise, Wolfenstien offers some refreshing mechanincs will still keeping true to the classic FPS elements that make the genre so popular. It offers plenty of options to stealth around; when the enemies start rolling in it offers some serious firepower. Nearly every weapon has an unlockable alternate firing mode and can be duel welded. With the lasercraftwerk, this game's equivalent of the gravity gun, you can do all kinds of stuff as you find new attachemnts for it, although its feels a little limited due to specific surfaces you can use it on. It also can provide a helping hand when your low on ammo and need a boost in firepower. The manual leaning is much preferable to an automatic system, although the controls are a little strange. I especially liked the no nonsense health value; get shot and the number goes down, get one the various helath kits in the game and the number goes up, if its gets to 0 you die. The armor is the same. Although a little unrealistic(especially with the armor), its provides a refreshing idea instead of the overused 'immersive' health. Stealth is also quite good. Sneaking behind walls and shooting commanders when no one is looking gives me a thrill like no other. An early game choice determines whether you use stealth/lockpicking(my choice) or explosives/grenades(I think). Overall, some refershing ideas give the game a different look and feel then most FPS's.   Now that my glowing review is over, we get to the not so great parts. Its just a couple so I made a list instead.      Towards the end of the game, I felt like it fouced more on heavy firepower than slinking throught level with stealth. I'm a huge fan of stealth so it got a little much towards the end(but it wasn't really that bad, just my personal preference)    Technology wise, the game has some major issues. A 50 gig download is unacceptable for a 10 hour game. It leads to horrendously long downloads for people with bad internet, and I couldn't put it on my SSD, making load time quite long, which got old real quick when i was restarting multiple times as I neared the end.    The game has some audio issues where the sound will mute if you fire different guns quickly, but this only happened four or five times.    It also has some texture pop issues. I only noticed it once but it was really obvious and broke the immersion. Other reviewers seem to state it happens more often.    Finally the game's cutscenes are frame capped at 30 Fps. It's not awful, but its definetaly noticable when lots of things are flying around.   Overall this game is thrilling, adrenaline-pumping, and a little bit disheartening. Some things the Nazis do in the game are quite appaling, but they really show the cold killing machine they were. Plus you kill an absolute buttload of them. When you take away the story, the mechanics, the characters, all the AAA fluff, this game is about killing Nazis. And that's a game I'd like to play.

I'm first going to start with a personal opinion on Wolfenstein: The New Order. It is an extremely great game, with a marvellously well-written plot, and packed to the brim with intensive action shooter scenes, in which you have to fight as if your life really depended on it. The game is well worth the money spent and is even better when discounted. The mix between old school and new school make this game a well-balanced one between the old Wolfenstein, and the new series of Wolfenstein.  Pros are as follows:  1) Great detail on the environment itself, the textures and effects are very clear and enjoyable.  2) Action scenes will make sure you don't get bored of any mission you play, and even offers you a selection between Stealth and Guns Blazing to get the job done.  3) The story itself is a magnificently written one, with characters each with their own personalities, histories and conflicts.  4) Vast range of weaponry, featuring multiple attachments or gadgets will greatly increase the variety at which you might want to deal with your enemies. Just crush them all, no matter how you do it.  5) The range of enemies is vast, and they are not some sort of stupid AI, they will know how to deal with you and will prove to be a challenge. True, some may work with a pattern, but some enemies are smarter than others and will be unpredictable, this means more of a challenge, but making it fun to expect the most from every shooter.  6) If the game's soundtrack also affects your playing experience, I can tell you there is some beautifully suitable music worthy of a Wolfenstein game, adapted perfectly to every scene.  7) Brutal, graphic, gorey but very, very, very, very enjoyable and fun to play.  Cons are as follows:  1) Sometimes it may feel as if the game slows down a bit. Yes, it does do that about twice throughout, but thankfully not frequent.  2) Even though brutal and graphic is a Pro, it can also be listed as a con for those who don't have as much a strong stomach. So be prepared.  3) Sometimes Wolfenstein trying to be both the old and new Wolfenstein may get a little bit in the way and you might find the game to go off track, but luckily, this is just a minor con, and you can quickly get back into the feel exactly as you want it.  So that's my review on Wolfenstein: The New Order, hope it's informative and will help you consider getting this game, it's well worth the price, and well worth the effort put into it to make it one of the best shooters out there, and forever be out there.

Let me start by saying; If you have a AMD graphics card like me - you might have some problems getting the game to run smoothly. It only took me 20 minutes though to find out what things I needed to do to get the game to look good and run smoothly - it's not that hard and there is a lot of tutorails and help you can get. Not all AMD cards will have the same problems as I did though.  The story is interesting and the characters are GREAT - usually in a shooter I don't care about any characters but in this game they all have very charming personalities and interesting stories. The shooting feels very good and satisfying - there's a lot of guns and you don't have a limit of how many you can carry (which is rare in modern shooters). There are some missions which kind of force you to play stealthy, but that's alright because those missions involve a lot of story development.  When it comes to how the game looks the textures are not that great, even on Ultra it still looks like a game from 2011. The aesthetic of the game however is very good. And the animation, even on the characters, is better than most games. So what the game doesn't have in texture quality it makes up with great aesthetic and animation quality. Personally graphics have never mattered a lot to me as long as they're not terrible - which they are not at all.   Sound design is through the roof. Very good indeed. The voice acting is very good.  Even though the game doesn't have multiplayer (which it doesn't have to have) it still has extra game modes you can unlock. The difficulty of the game is as it should be - there are 5 difficulties, if you pick the easiest you'll get easy, and if you pick the hardest you'll be dying a lot. As you'd expect. There are multiple ways to get to the goal in missions, and you get to chose between being stealthy or being Rambo most of the time. Health regeneration is in there in a very small portion - you can only regenerate 20 health, then you have to find health packs in the level. Which is a nice compromise between the way old shooters did it and the way modern shooters does it.  I recommend Wolfenstein: The New Order to any shooter fans. Because it's a DAMN GOOD shooter with a fantastic story with fantastic characters to support it.  Gameplay: 9/10 Story: 9/10 Graphics: 7/10 Animation: 8.5/10 Sound: 10/10 Overall Game: 9/10

Wolfenstein: The New Order is a real gem of a game. This has been said many times before, but it really is nice to see the return of several old-school shooter characteristics. Dual-wielding guns, hunting for secrets, finding armor and health packs, planning routes around levels with a map instead of walking down continuous hallways broken up by firefights. I'd forgotten how fun these kinds of games can be.  A lot of games also tout a play-your-way format while having one thing in mind and punishing you for doing something different. TNO could have fallen into this trap and offered an action shooter with stealth elements reluctantly included, but the aforementioned open maps lend themselves for run-and-gun or stealth play. I appreciate this for the replay value alone.  In terms of shooting, you can't go wrong with this title. There is a nice selection of weapons, and upgrades along with skills add further options. Gunplay feels visceral, further compounded by large amounts of actual viscera. In the end, that's all this game had to do to accomplish its goal, and it does this well. Add in the future elements, and we're really in business now.  I leave you all with a quote from B.J. which, in my opinion, sums up the game pretty well:  '♥♥♥♥ you, Nazi ♥♥♥♥ing spaceman.'

This game builds a terrific world in it's alt-1960 universe. Not just the Nazi-infestation, but the varied cast of characters you live and die with that form the backdrop of our hero's adventure. Great voice acting, terrific story. For me, it was an 11-hour nearly non-stop campaign that I had to see through to completion.   No multiplayer, but that's hardly an issue for me. This was well worth it.  PROS:  * Amazing alt-1960 story  * Stunning graphics -- some screenshots practially look like art.  * Wonderful soundtrack; subtle, but when it kicks in... damn.  * Game splits into two 'timelines' depending on a (very tough) early choice. This has a minor ripple effect throughout the rest of the game. Playthrough averages about 11 hours for one 'timeline'.  * Holy cow, this game visits almost every location you can imagine. I won't even spoil it.   CONS:  * Horrid texture and asset pop-in (like RAGE), but there are ways to minimize this that I won't get into. Google it.   * Additionally, textures sometimes do not load full-res. Or worse, some objects will render half with full quality, and the bottom half (for example) at low quality. Sometimes entire walls just stay low quality. And the compression artifacts stand out. (I did not try turning off texture compression in the graphics settings -- YMMV.)  * The game can sometimes be cheap by spawning in enemies behind you, even after you THINK you've cleared a room. This is incredibly unfair, but I found the best thing to do in those particular battles is to just try and RUN through and get to the marker.   4.5/5

Wolfenstein: The New Order is a 'soft reboot' of the Wolfenstein franchise, and as per tradition, you take control of William 'B.J.' Blazkowicz, but this time, there's more to the man than just brawn. The game delves into Blazkowicz's mind and though process, giving the player another dimension to his character and actually root for him and his motivations that develop throughout the story. This whole game revolves around a 'what if' scenario, if the Axis Powers, specifically The Third Reich. Within all of this chaos of the world becoming a hellhole and twisted upside down, Blazkowicz is tasked to stop the Nazi war machine, with one goal in mind, ending the figurehead General Deathshead.  The characters you meet are memorable in their own aspect and own motivations on why they fight the regime, and adds a real and evident human element to the gameplay. Even the Nazis are portrayed in a somewhat of a human light as they have casual banter and conversation here and there as you progress through the game. They go thoughout their lives caring for one another, but never for anyone outside their 'race'. You see a realistic, but not biased side of what the Nazis were in this game, which makes the world feel more real and believable. In the game also exists, newspaper clippings, records (that one can listen to) to add to more of the idea that 'a world like this could exists, here's what changes'.   The gameplay is nothing special, nothing innovative, everything works as it should, and very fluidly as well, but there's no mechanics that no one hasn't seen yet. Returning to classic FPS roots is the inclusion of a health system that requires attention when reduced, rather than just simply taking cover and recharging health, like most shooters now are today, which could be a good or bad thing, on one hand it forces one to take more care in enagaging enemies recklessly, and analyze where the next potential health drop is, and the other hand when health is scarce, one will constantly be obliterated by the heavily armed soldiers later in the game. There's also a intergrated perk system which is unlocked by attaining certain requirements in the game (headshot enemies to unlock, etc.)   It's a game that makes you wonder and think more and invest yourself in the story, rather than just running and gunning enemies (which you can do), which is what many games try to do nowadays, but sometimes falls short.   PROS -Well crafted narrative -Mostly memorable characters -Solid gunplay -Unique setpieces and environments that really give an idea of the world portrayed -Voice acting and performances on point -BAMF saving the world -Boss battles -Retro-futurism done right  -Realistic portrayal of characters and motivations -No holds barred look at the brutality and insanity of the enemy -No issues running game at 60FPS   CONS -Anticlimactic and lackluster ending  -Decisions really don't affect the story much -Textures are eh at times and pop in more so -Graphics are nice, but only in certain environments, otherwise its ok  -Pretty short campaign (longer than most, but still fairly short at 10-12 hours) -Gets a bit contrived and unrealistic towards the end of the game  -Dual wielding is nice but somewhat useless  Wolfenstein: The New Order doesn't do much to innovate, but that's because it's not trying to, it's trying to tell a story with refined modern mechanics in tandem with classic gameplay elements that harken back to the early days of FPS. It gets a lot of things right more than wrong. It's going to be the same gameplay you've seen before in every other shooter, but it's the story that will captivate and entertain you, so if you're interested in a good narrative with solid gameplay mechanics, then definitely go for this game, you will more than likely enjoy this game.

I have to admit when I first heard that the Wolfenstein franchise was getting a reboot I had a number of mixed emotions. While the game was a bit before my time, I have to say that the thought of Bethesda remaking such an iconic series seemed unrealistic to me. Remembering how groundbreaking the first game was, I wondered how such a game could live up to it's legacy. Recreating this critically acclaimed franchise which had been virtually untouched for so long seemed like such a tantamount task for any developer to take on; but MachineGames pulled it off with it's hit: Wolfenstein The New Order.  Entering the Wolfenstein franchise as a new player I found myself to be quite entrigued by the immediate introduction into action in the game. having never played the previous games from the '90s I was unsure if I was going to enjoy the game or not upon first entry. Of course I'd seen the videos from E3 of all of the gameplay footage and such alike but I was unsure whether I would truly be imersed into the game or not. Well, I guess I found out later when four hours had passed and the sun was down. With this game I was expecting any old shoot 'em up action packed FPS, but I found myself pleasantly surprised at the end of the game. Set in a world where the nazis have conquered the planet after mystical occult powers lead them to their victor in WWII, the Nazi War machine now rules the globe. The main character B.J. Blackowitcz' main directive after somehow awakening from a decade and a half long state of paralysis is to find the resist and bring down the war machine. Now this might sound like your classic FPS however a combination of fantastic character immersion as well as a gripping plot development creates an experience which really gets you empathizing with the characters in the game. I couldn't stop playing this game and when I made it to the end found myself feeling very satisfied with the all around experience. I have to say that this game is a perfect embodiement of what I'm looking for in a modern day FPS. Looking forward to the next game!

Wolfenstein: The New Order surprised me. Not only because the game actually turned out good, but it's most redeeming factor is the story.  Who would've thought Wolfenstein would have transformed from a extremely linear 2D classic shooter to this? The graphics look very nice, the audio is well done, the guns feel very good and the story is amazing.  The story see's the player take control of William 'B.J.' Blazkowicz, which anyone who has played Wolfenstein before will be familiar with. Blazkowicz suffers a critical head injury and this is where the main story point kicks in - Blazkowicz wakes up in 1960, 14 years after the start of the game, inside a insane asylum. In this alternate universe, the Nazi's won World War II and there is not a stretch of land on the planet that is not under their control. They have amassed a huge amount of futurisitic technology which will see the player engage with not only Nazi soldiers but armoured dogs, robots and drones.  The story of the game also tackles the grim reality of World War II and what the Nazi's in particular were trying to do. Without going in to too much detail some of the issues that the game tackles are; Concentration camps and PoW's, experimention and the brutality of war. Some of it is eye opening and some of it is genuinly just good story telling.  The gunplay feels great, the guns feel very meaty and as if you are firing your bullets with a lot of power behind them. Just like you would expect from a game like Wolfenstein.   Wolfenstein: The New Order surprised me and I thuroughly enjoyed my time with the game.

Pros: Some truly uncomfortable horror scenes, compelling story, well-developed characters, highly destructible dynamic environments, satisfying gore, action straight out of a 80's Ahnold movie, and special effects worth writing home about. You will not get bored playing this game - it's clear that a lot of thought went into it. It even has a 'lite' stealth system and accompanying choices of how to strategically approach each situation. It also doesn't hold your hand through every individual scenario ala Call Of Duty (and this is coming from a COD fan.) While it is linear, there is a greater degree of choice involved here in how to attack it. The AI is very, very good. They're not shooting gallery pop-ups hiding behind a single piece of cover. They move to flank, stalk, investigate, retreat etc. Hide in a room to catch your breath for too long, and one of them will run up, throw a grenade inside, and retreat for cover again to flush you out.  Cons: It ate ♥♥♥♥ and crashed to desktop until I installed the latest AMD/Catalyst update. I have a high-end gaming-specific computer, and it still stutters frequently on the sound - particularly during in-game cut scenes. While not nearly as linear as COD, it is far from being as open-approach as Dishonored (which it seems to be getting frequent comparisons to for some odd reason.) No multiplayer of any kind - this would have been a badass co-op game.   In summary, if you're on the fence at all: BUY IT. As long as your system can support it, it's worth every penny to the devoted shooter fan.

Wolfenstein is not the old school FPS return to glory that it has been touted as, I am sad to say. It looks great, the weapons have a solid punch to them, and the esthetics are pretty damn nice, but about halfway through the game it all goes wrong. Everything becomes tedious and repetitive, as you reach the point where you've seen all there is to see when it comes to both weapons, enemies, and challenges, and things just become more of the same. While at first the game is reminicent of the old school shooter in the guise of a modern game, that at least I had hoped the game would be, soon the mini-bosses you face at first become standard and mundane bulletsponges that you meet in every level. And the gunplay of the game grows boring quite quick as well, despite there being the occational upgrade to some weapons that give them a new alternate function, as there aren't all that many weapons and for the most part you rely on just one or two weapons, unless you run out of ammo and have to switch to an alternate weapon until you pick up more ammo for the better weapon.   The game relies overly much on cutscenes to deliver the narrative, that at times are wonderful, but eventually turn tedious and overstay their welcome. They get in the way of the play of the game, cutting it off just as the flow is begining to pick up the pace and you get into the action. At times they are also infuriating, pointless, and serve no purpose beyond padding the length of the game. At one point you trigger a cutscene and get ambushed by an enemy, who then delivers a monologue that does nothing to serve neither the current mission nor the plot, then you turn the tables on your attacker, all in the same cutscene, then you get control back and get a Quick Time Event to kill your attacker. Why? Why would they include this? It slowed down the pace of what was supposed to be a rushed mission, and that is it.   Wolfenstein: the New Order has the chimes of greatness, and there are some rather impressive boss battles (though they are usually of the 'run around until you figure out the weakness/pattern of the boss'-variant while posing little danger and little challenge), but the second half of the game feels empty and rushed, filled with just 'more' of what you've already seen in the couple of hours. I did enjoy the game, but past the halfway point I was bored and completed it merely for the sake of completing it, not because it was challenging or because I wanted to see what came next. It must also be said that the game is short, even with the cutscene padding. I finished the game in just about 9 hours, and I have no intention of going for a second playthrough, despite the obvious choice-scene in the start of the game that just screams 'you should play the game twice and see the differences'. Sorry, MachineGames, but the game you made here is by no means interesting enough for that. I'd rather play Return to Castle Wolfenstein, that was much more fun.

At least I waited until it cost me less than five bucks.

Having been a fan of the Wolfenstein series from the beginning, I was really excited when this game was announced as I had a lot of fun playing Wolfenstein '09. I had almost no fun playing this one.  PROS:  - A cool premise for continuing the franchise.  CONS:   - Abyssmal level designs throughout. Run through corridors until you get to an open area, usually circular and repeat. There are only a couple of exceptions to this layout, one being a destroyed train amidst the rubble of a bridge which is actually the only level I semi-enjoyed.   - You go to the moon to fight Nazi's, super cool idea, but you only get to play on the actual moon for a minute and then you only have a few flying drones you can take down and then you're back into another corridor.  - Not one but two horrible sex scenes that are so out of place, they're ridiculous. Did this game really need that? Nope. It cheapens the series.  -Tries too hard to be 'deep' BJ's ramblings made me want the Nazi's to win  - Missed opportunities. The moment you're going to town in a mech suit is cool but you're in a confined space and it's over as soon as it begins.    - Tedious one man submarine sequence. It felt tacked on as did all the underwater stuff.  - Scavenger hunts. I understand in a FPS wanting to slow things down but at least it can be a fun diversion. I would have rather had the option to play with crayons and draw something in dum-dum's room than to look for crap for all these lazy NPC's.  At the end of the day, this game is, for me anyway, a HUGE disappointment because it does nothing exceptional or outstanding and doesn't introduce anything really new or interesting into the genre or franchise. There are some cool ideas but they're squandered aimlessly and, at the end of it all, there's just nothing memorable or even good about it.    4 out of 10

I enjoy Wolfenstein The New Order and despite a few bugs and the fact it can sometimes be confusing as to where to go if for some reason the HUD dissapears, the game was excellent. Pros:     The enemy actually speaks in German and for the most part, is highly accurate for the time period. Collectible locations are sometimes rediculously hard to find or figure out unless you're either a pro at doing these or are cheating.   Final Verdict: 9/10 because no game is perfect and I wanted there to be at least a DLC expansion which might came out...we never know. Yet its downfalls weren't big enough to make it unenjoyable. I beat the whole game in about 9 hours on the normal difficulty (I switched it to the easiest difficulty towards the very end just so I could be done with it).  Great looking visuals, immersive sound, halfway decent voice acting for an FPS game, but the gameplay is just too flawed to make this an actually fun game.  Shooting in this game is the best part! Then you have many long segments where you aren't shooting or you aren't supposed to shoot - hunting around for stuff like this is Ether One or Dear Esther (for example, there's a section where you're looking for mold - I'm not kidding), or sneaking around with limited weapons. First of all, this is a problem because I got this game thinking it would be an intense, fast paced FPS. When you throw in these inane 'look around for something' quests and these slow-paced stealth sections, you're keeping me from doing what I want to do with my limited free time. Second of all, the stealth gameplay is just not fun. It's not even a problem with the mechanics of stealth in this game, it's just that sneaking around, waiting, and sneaking some more isn't really fun when you're looking for an intense, fast-paced experience.  But, even if they got rid of all that other stuff, they managed to mess up the shooting gameplay as well. At first, when they only have the weak enemy types that go down in a few hits, the game is quite fun. Even with that, though, the guns they give you aren't really precise, so even if you're aiming down the sights, it's not easy to pull off those headshots, giving you less of that feeling of mastery and control that you can get from other FPS games. That's fine if running and gunning is a viable tactic, but if you do that, it seems you'll take lots of damage and you have to find medkits to heal yourself. I know people claim to hate regenerating health, but I honestly would've had more fun if, during combat, I could just run and gun, hide for a bit to heal up, then do it some more. There's a lot of other ways to fix that annoyance than regenerating health, though.  More about the combat - as I said, when there's weak enemies that go down in a few hits, it's fun. However, they quickly start introducing heavily armored enemies. They kinda have weak points, but it's still going to be a frustrating experience taking them down. It's just not fun when you have to empty entire clips into enemies, even if you're hitting their weak points, until they fall down. It ruins the fun pace of the game because you have to pop out, shoot, then duck back behind cover, and repeat until they're dead. You can't just run and strafe and shoot because you'll just take too much damage. It's possible I was not clear on what parts of these enemies were 'weak points' or what the best strategies were for taking down these enemies - I would blame that on the game's lack of clear feedback and guidance. These enemies occur way too frequently, and they continuously introduce stronger and stronger enemies that take more and more time to take down. It's just not fun. Compare this to games like Bulletstorm, Call of Juarez, or Shadow Warrior. They manage to keep the challenge up while still making the combat satisfying.  Also, the weapon switching is atrocious. I think you should've been able to switch weapons while the game is paused. They give you so many different weapons, which is great, but because of how weapon switching works, you'll find yourself not feeling like you should ever switch it up unless you run out of ammo. Why give players lots of weapons if you don't give them an easy way to decide between them and switch?  Also, I know people complain about modern games 'hand holding' players, but if it improves the fun-per-minute, I'm all for it. In the case of this game, there were many times where I wasn't sure where I was supposed to go so I had to spend time wandering around. That's just not fun. When you have a limited time to play games, you want to spend it having as much fun as possible - so if they did a better job of indicating where to go, the game would've been at least less annoying.  So, overall, the FPS combat is the best part and it's rife with gameplay issues that make it frustrating and unsatisfying. The parts that aren't FPS are even worse - they are boring, slow, and totally not what you would want if you're looking for a fast, exciting FPS. However, I did at least enjoy the story, writing, voice acting, and animation during the cutscenes - the characters were memorable and their faces when talking didn't look too 'off'. Also, the visuals and sound in this game are quite polished and really help with the immersion. However, there just isn't the same intelligence, ingenuity, and creativity in the actual gameplay design.   I primarily recommend a game based on the amount of fun I have for the time I am playing the game. Wolfenstein: The New Order, only manages to be fun about 20% of the time through the game, so look elsewhere for a fun, fast-paced, thoughtfully-designed shooter.

After playing through this game, for three days, 100% and playing on two different play throughs, I can safely say Wolfenstien: The New Order is not just one of the best FPS' to come out so far this year, but one of the best to come out in a long time; and its totally worth the $60! Everything from the story, gameplay, graphics are extremely well made and presented. To get the boring stuff out of the way, the visuals of the game are incredible and really do bring out a next generation feeling with its well made models, sleak areas and weapons and spectacular violence gibs that go flying through out the game!   The story is surprisingly great! Due to being single player only, a lot of detail went into the world and enviorments that you go through, and because of that you can really get sucked into the games world that it presents! Characters are all well done and overall Machine Games did an amazing job pulling off this end. But now for the most important of everything here; the gameplay.  The gameplay is just friggin rad! It combines classic FPS elements and modern elements and creates this incredible game which I hope future developers look to when making future titles. The game allows for stealth in some sections, which comes off as a nearly perfected feature for players of many tastes. In those stealth sections, you can go guns blazing if you want to, but the stealth is fast, quick, strategic and very enjoyable overall because of it! The health system is perfected with this balence of old and new, using health kits to heal up while you still have regenerating health. The overcharge ability for your health is also great since it turns those useless health items you find in secret areas into useful tools to create more destruction against the Nazis! Its incredible to finally get back into the old school way of hunting for healing items!  The gunplay is one part that got me sucked in the moment I saw footage for the game, and it does not dissapoint. Its fast, frantic and gives you some crazy adrenaline rushes at times! Its old school shooting from way back in the day but its back in the modern day, combining big, powerful weapons to use against armies of foes and giant bosses! You can acquire upgrades too, which give you more advantages to some of your guns. But dang, it is so much fun duel wielding two large machine guns and unloading them on unrelenting enemies!  The AI is challenging too, so where ever that odd rumor is coming from it needs to pipe down, cause enemies will actually use cover, get together to gang up, will crouch and shoot at you if you are under neath floors, its great! There are also perks you can gain from doing certain actions through the game. Some are absolutely easy while others may be extremely annoying (See the Assault Rifle Perk). The cover system they put in the game is very handy for taking out those foes who can mess you up if they see you for a second.  And the boss battles. Not gonna go into too much detail, but DAMN! It is great to see bosses again, like actual boss fights, not some QTE bull crap or something else that doesn't involve a fight or gameplay. These bosses are awesome, powerful and really rad when you see them and destroy them! The final boss in particular is what I personally have been waiting for after a long time in FPS gaming. An actual big bad you get to face down rather then mash the space bar or tap the hell out of X because the game devs were too lazy or wanted some kind of 'real' fight. Bleh! This game gets it right on every angle!  Just overall, the game play is pheonominal. Combine that with the good story and amazing visuals, you have yourself a fantastic title. Its well worth the $60 USD, but if times are tough for you, nab it during a sale, it will be worth every penny; believe me. Over all I give this game my highest of reccommendations and if you can, buy it now!

Overall this game has restored my faith in the FPS genre and given me hope that more developers will realise that there is a market for these types of shooters and not just the generic online shooters riddled with microtransactions.  10/10 great job guys I hope you do a sequel.

Wolfenstein: The New Order provides the perfect mix of action stealth and story. The gameplay is not centered around one form of combat, and allows the player to develop through perks (benefits gained by achieving certain tasks) which play style he or she prefers. Although the game allows the player a majority of the time to choose how to play the game, it does, at times, force the player to use the stealth system orthe fast paced action system. When this does happened it doesn't feel forced, but instead feels more like a fluid transition from one play style to the other.   The characters and cutscenes in Wolfenstein are interesting, exciting and have a certain depth to them that many modern fps games lack. The story has an underlying theme about the treatment of certain peoples during World War II, and although Nazi's never created giant robots they are god damn fun to kill, and each enemy is well-balanced. When playing on the hardest difficulty the levels require a certain sense of creativity to beat which makes the game even more fun.  The scenery in Wolfenstein is only okay, but what makes the graphics interesting and different is the rather subtle filter applied to it.   This is one of the best Fps games I've played and I have to say that it is definitely worth the price.

It's a fairly solid game overall. I can live without multiplayer; unless the game is a dedicated multiplayer game, MP seems like a crappy, tacked-on afterthought anyways. I prefer a solid SP or MP game rather than two sub-par halves crammed together.  As far as the game goes, id Tech 5 is a wicked engine. Some deformable terrain, damage realistically displayed on enemies (sometimes graphically so, as the energy weapons later on will show), without being terribly system-demanding, and always seemed smooth. I find it worth noting I never once had any glitches or slowdown in this game. Truly a rarity these days (especially when Bethesda is involved, COUGH COUGH).  The story is quite interesting, and even though some of the characters are a bit flat and undeveloped at times, and there's a couple of instances where for the sake of plot you need to suspend your disbelief, it's fairly believable. Plus, you get to shoot space Nazis on the ♥♥♥♥ing Moon. With lasers. It's like Stanley Kubrick directed 2001: A Space Odyssey with Nazis in it. And lasers.  The gameplay is top-notch. Everything is fluid, from movements, to context sensitive abilities like vaulting, and the stealth/cover systems are as about as non-cumbersome as you can get. You're not stuck to surfaces, and can transition quickly from cover to cover. Not that it's necessary to; unlike that one section everyone remembers from Return to Castle Wolfenstein, stealth in this game is entirely OPTIONAL. It may make your life easier, such as in taking out Commanders to prevent them from calling reinforcements, but you can also just dual-wield and mow down everything that lives. Gunplay in this is absolutely BRUTAL. Dismembered limbs, exploding heads, exploding bodies, stabbing people in the face, chest, temple, leg...if you've ever wanted the definitive Nazi-killing simulator, The New Order is it.

I am a big fan of the ex-Starbreeze guys, but something is missing from Wolfenstein that keeps it from being a strong GOTY contender. The technical problems on PC when trying to activate basic functionality like MSAA were a big hassle, but more importantly, the old school teleportation solution to transitioning between levels felt really detrimental to the experience of playing the game.   For example the much hyped train story sequence - it looked really impressive in preview videos, but in the actual game the sequence felt crammed in between two levels. They tried to create an oppressive world, but the constant teleportation between story sequences and geographically distant locations (even using ridiculous stealth helicopters) made it really hard to immerse yourself in the world and feel the oppression.   I mean, imagine how effective that train sequence would have been if it had been preceded by escaping the military checkpoint of the previous level, hiding with a fake identity among other civilians, presenting forged paperwork to get on the train and getting to explore the train as a detailed location. All of this while being paranoid about being detected and with various stealth gameplay elements to make it possible to actually be detected. But instead of doing this, the game just cuts to the story sequence in question, which completely lacks tension as a result ...  Many of the levels that you 'teleport' to could have been edited to be physically connected to the resistance headquarters hub, which would have required some effort from the developer, but would have vastly improved the immersion into the game world. Exploring the secret tunnels around the resistance headquarters in some short missions was a really fun experience, and I just wish that the developer had made more of an effort to facilitate that kind of connectedness between the hub and all the missions in the game.

Wolfenstein: The New Order. A massive disappointment. Why is this below-mediocre clone of CoD singleplayer calls itself 'Wolfenstein'? Why do the visuals look like they're from 6 years ago, despite the game having super-heavy hardware requirements and 50GB (!!! WTF) install size.  Oh, and the reviews? Filthy lies, every single word. Let me quote from Wikipedia (and yes, I read this _after_ I tried to play the game):  'Reviews praised the combat mechanics of the game. Daniel Hindes of GameSpot felt that the intensity and variety of the combat in the game has granted the series 'a breath of fresh air,' and believes that it managed to fulfil his nostalgic expectations from the series. Metro's David Jenkins said that the combat in the game is the 'real deal,' and named it one of the best recent single-player shooter games. The stealth sections of the game also received praise, with Simon Miller of  VideoGamer.com  lauding the shooting and stealth mechanics, naming the former as 'solid.'  It's railroaded, heavily scripted run-forward-and-gun-things-down. Oh, but occasionally you get to perform a STEALTH TAKEDOWN from behind! With a knife! And the game won't even tell you when you can do it (except for the first time you're presented with an opportunity) - you have to GUESS! So novel!  'Colin Moriarty of IGN considered the narrative and characters one of the best points of the game, stating that it's where it 'really shines.' Metro's Jenkins also praised the story, stating that the mix of tones is 'bizarre but obviously intentional.' Bah. Dialogue feels like it's written by first year journalism students. Characters are wooden. Overall, D-, but ultimately F for not even trying.  'The graphical design of the game received commentary from reviewers. GameSpot's Hindes praised the visual design. Taljonick of GamesRadar stated that the game's level design contributes to his enjoyment of the shooting sequences. He also praised the size of the levels, enjoying the possibility of participating in a large gunfight 'with some sort of plan.' Digital Spy's Liam Martin shared mixed commentary on the design, noting that the character models are animated well, but the game is 'hardly a shining example of next-gen graphical potential.' Wolfenstein: The New Order is a game that is an absolute rip off at $60. The story is bland and predictable, and the gameplay has absolutely nothing original to add to the genre, it was mildly enjoyable at first, but becomes tedious and repetitive after the first 20 minutes.   When you begin the game you start out with only a knife, and you assume that as you progress you will unlock more and more weapons to pummel Nazis with. It turns out, once you find the Assault Rifle, you have found the weapon you will use for the rest of the game. You end up with a selection of knife, AR, shotgun, pistol, LaserKraftWerk(LKW), and marksman rifle(A pitiful selection for an 'Shoot 'em up' game). The only two weapons that you get ammo often enough to use are the AR and the LKW, both of which are bland and unsatisfying. The Marksman was great fun to use, but over the 10 hour playthrough, I found maybe 30 bullets for it.  The LKW is used to lengthen the game like a teenager uses a thesaurus to meet the word count on his essay. You repeatedly have to use the laser cutter feature of the gun to carve holes in crates, in vents, and to cut chains. Instead of just opening vents like a normal game, you are forced to draw the hole with your laser, and once you have completed a loop, the vent falls out. This often leads to you not making a large enough hole, and having to trim the edges to fit through. I spent over an hour, in the HQ doing chores. You have to find toys, documents, and power tools for people around the HQ, and it is an absolute disgrace that a AAA game company would resort to such blatant Artificial Game Lengtheners(AGL).  The perks are useless, and through an entire playthrough, I only unlocked about half of them. One you must kill two enemies with a single grenade, but the game gives you grenades so infrequently, that when a 2-for-1 opportunity comes up, you are out of nades, not to mention you can only carry 2.  This game is an easy 2/10, one star for the fact that I actually completed the campaign, and one star for actually looking pretty nice. -8 for all of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that I would expect from some indiegogo/kickstarter developer to try and pull. Please, don't buy this game, you are supporting shoddy Devs, that use cheap tricks and sleight of hand to make a garbage game look like a AAA title, don't support this kind of behaviour with devs.

Old Blood is a much better executed game with more replay value. I actually re-installed Old Blood after beating New Order. So what went wrong? The atmosphere for one...for those that are rolling their eyes (AKA: I beat this game in 30 min on ULTA HARD MODE), atmosphere is BIG, if you zoom through games you probably don't care, but I like the little touches in the world where a little brain matter splattered on a wall leading to a hallway through broken glass and debris builds on the anticipation leading into the next room. New order has some of that but it's not immersive, the details just aren't there (not talking about the graphics), it feels hollow and souless for the most part . There are some RPG elemets that take you out of the rhythm of what happened previously and frankly, I could have done without (sewer segments/rebel hideout). Another small gripe, it would have been nice to keep your perks when you start a new game after beating it on UBER. Also the 'timelines' mechanic...does not really add to the replay value. Don't really care about either one of the characters to see what the difference is especially since the ending is always the same (an ending that is a let down and does not add to the replay value either). If you have a big back catalog of unplayed games (especially after a good Steam sale event), skip this title, even with the Wolfenstein pedigree. You get more bang for you buck with Old Blood. Wolfenstein delivers exactly what I expected, over-the-top nonstop Nazi killing fun. Not only does it successfully revive the father of all shooter video games, it stands its own as an excellent modern day shooter. You can peak from cover freely just by holding the cover button and leaning in any direction you desire, making it easy to quickly duck down behind cover and shoot around corners. You can also dual wield anything! Dual wield assault rifles, dual wield shotguns, dual wield freakin sniper rifles that transform into automatic lazer guns! This game is just nonstop, consistent fun.   The story offered in 'The New Order' is fantastic. There's great voice over work to be found by all the characters, and the actual plot was the most creative thing I've had the pleasure of experiencing in years. I don't want to spoil too much, because I went into this game knowing absolutely nothing about the story, and loved it even more. The characters themselves are all interesting and having the short Headquarters missions where you have to help them out before your next mission really helped you feel like you were a part of the story itself. All of the action leads up to a fantastic finale that I was more than satisfied with.   Now let's talk about the tech behind the game. Here's where we run into a few major issues. This game is optimized terribly. And I say terribly, because my framerates struggled in many areas despite the graphics not even looking that great. The explosions look like something you would see in a PS2 game. Just bland yellow puffs of smoke that are only recognizable as explosions because of the sound effect. This is unacceptable, especially for a game being sold on 'next gen' hardware. In addition to some poor effects work, there's many areas in the game where the textures look so bad that I was wondering if that game was supposed to have a cell-shaded look to it. But none of these graphical issues were as bad as the screen tearing. Despite offering a vertical sync option in the settings, this game screen-tears like nothing I've ever seen. It's very disorienting trying to search for ammo when the top half of your screen is looking the other way. I'm not quite sure what is causing this issue, and I'm sure if you used a 3rd party program to enable vertical sync, it may fix the problem, but hopefully this issue is officially fixed for the game given some time.   Now let's talk about the gameplay. Make no mistake, just like it's predecessor, this is a LINEAR shooter. However, the developers managed to slip in some creative approaches to areas. I enjoyed having the option to find a secret metal grate that I could use my welding torch on so I could sneak into an area high above the enemies, and steathily take them out one by one to prevent reinforcements from arriving. There are several different paths in and around areas which makes for some great strategic planning and offers some replay value. Not only that, but the game is completely flooded with collectables hidden everywhere. And these aren't your simple types of modern day secret areas.. these are oldschool secret stashes that only the most seasoned oldschool shooter fan will know how to find.   So despite it's few technical issues like screen-tear and poor graphic quality, wolfenstein holds its own in a world diluted with first person shooters due to its fantastic gameplay mechanics and surprisingly creative story. Don't miss out on this one, this is your only chance to kill plenty of dem nazis.

FUN MIXED WITH DISSAPOINTMENT --------------------------------------  While being very much fun at times, this game overall fails to meet the high expectations set by the overwhelmingly positive reviews out there. Technical issues, utterly boring stealth sections, poor decisions regarding gameplay and setting and bland story are all factors that spoil the nazi-killing fun. While being refreshing for the FPS genre, Wolfenstein: The New Order is a missed chance to bring the old-skool formula back to its glorydays.  1. Technical issues The choice for the Id engine is an odd decision. While it admittingly delivers some damn nice background images and gives the game an artsy feel, it has some serious downsides. One is the gi-normous file size, with a whopping 44GB. Another is the texture pop-in, that seems to be typical for some implementations of this engine. Every time you make a turn, the texturing to the side of your FOV lags slightly. Especially in tight places with a lot of objects, this can really be annoying. While not hampering gameplay, it makes the game look kind of cheap. Another problem that spawns from this are the long loading times. Okay, back in the days we spend long times looking at loading screens. In this day and age, it kind of feels awkward. Oh, and the textures... Up close, they are simply a disaster. Black objects are smeared with the green ugliness typical for low-res texturing, and overall the objects look damn terrible.  2. Setting and storytelling First of, let me explain that I simply love the alternate history-theme. Nazis having won the war and ruling the planet, is damn terifying, and is very well played out in this game. Bits of newspaper articles lying around give a nice insight in how our favourite baddies did the trick, and the Germanic interpretations of popular 60's rock songs were down right hilarious (Die Käfer playing 'blaue U-boot'? I tip my hat to that one!).  But still, it doesn't feel right. The atmosphere is waaaaaaay too serious. The game keeps setting the focus on the hardships and the terror of the war, the powerlessness of the conquered, and so on. This would be a great angle for a realistic WWII shooter, but here it is so out of place! I mean, WTF? A dude dual-wielding auto-shotguns against giant nazi mechs, Panzerhunde, and even frickin' SPACE NAZIS! How can you possibly ask anyone to take this seriously? I get it, the makers tried to give the story and the characters some depth, and they succeed. A little bit. There's a love interest, and B. J. Blascowizc has these internal monologues giving some insight in his feelings, and he has these huge blue puppy-eyes in the cutscenes. But screw that. You can't present him as an unstoppable, primitive nazi-killing machine, and still trying to make him a real person. You just can't reconcile these things, and it's plain obvious throughout the entire game. What this game could seriously have used is some more tongue-in-cheek humor, more Tarantino-like moments (the scene in the train is an instant classic, though!), more bravado, more over-the-top character presentation. It just feels like the makers couln't reach a decision on what it actually was that they were trying to be: a B-movie style game, or an A-movie story. They tried to be both, but that simply doesn't work. The right choice would've been to be a kick-♥♥♥ B-movie. Related to this, I can tell you that the story is laughably poor after the first few hours. Some awesome antagonists are presented, but then disappear for nearly the entirety of the game! This takes away any drive to go out and kill these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. As for the rest, the story is incredibly straightforward, and features some initially interesting characters. Lack of real interaction with them, or overall lack in storytelling, renders you not giving a flying s*** about them in the end. And that end is incredibly derpy. Something with atomic bomb and stuff. Whatever. Finally, there's the setting in which the gameplay takes place. While level-design is quite good, it just lacks the right atmosphere in my opinion. The levels are often way to lighted, too familiar looking. It lacks some real evilness. Entire cities made of concrete? A Gibraltar bridge? An exposition? Meh. Not really frightening. I had hoped for more creepy settings, like in the previous titles in this franchise. Even the bloody concentration camp bades in beautiful summer light, which makes it look more like a holiday camp. Come on, the reality of these things was dreadful and horrific. At least try to portrey this dread and horror in the atmosphere and setting!  3. Gameplay Shooting Nazis in the face! Blowing their limbs clean off! What could possibly be more awesome then that? So how can gameplay even be an issue, you might ask? Let me explain. First of all, there is just not enough of it. There are long cutscenes with bad story, breaking down the pace. In actual gameplay, there are inexplicably long intervals of exactly jack s*** happening. Exploring sewers full of nothing? Empty corridors? A moon walk in near-zero G WITHOUT Nazis to shoot? What the hell? Not my bloody idea of fun. This title is portrayed as a game that is purely about killing nazis, but it fails to deliver on exactly this aspect! The sections in which you do get to f*** s*** up are nice, though. Gunplay feels solid, and it's awesome to completely wreck a place. But you spend the entirety of the games shooting the same exotic toys, like: a pistol! An assault rifle! A sniper rifle! A shotgun! Woopty-f***ing-doo. Boring. Ammo is scarce and enemies drop almost nothing of it. Boring. The game actively pushes you to use cover and lean to shoot. Boring. I think we all expected doing stand-up gunfights with long triggertimes, not cover-to-cover fighting, picking your shoots carefully? A shame that MachineGames decided to use the modern appraoch to the FPS genre, instead of using the perks of the old-school titles. Nope, the old-school aspect seems to be largely restricted to health-kits, armor pickups, and boss-fights. A pitty.  The biggest anoyance for last. The stealth mechanics. Okay, great to give your players a bit of freedom in playstyle, but this? The game requires you to a) be stealthy or b) face impossible odds with hardly any ammo to come out alive. So there goes your freedom. Or it just forces this style on you. I like stealth-gameplay a lot, but here it is tottaly out of place, and terribly implemented. Stealth means just following the obvious paths through -guess what!- airvents. However, you can simply walk over to your enemy crouched. He will never hear you, he is always placed neatly with his back to you, and is incredibly stupid. 'Hmmm, somebody lurking over there? Let's totally not check that out'. 'Hmmm, I think there's a guy over there pointing a gun right at my face, but he's crouched, so I can't see him!'. Yes, the crouch button is simply a 'now you see me, now you don't' button. Sticking to the shadows? No need. Walking slowly? No need. No need whatsoever to have any skill at this. And the amount of these stealth-sections are enormous. So we have and 'stealth' sections, and long cutscenes, and parts with nothin happening? Turns three quarters of this game into a massive snoozefest, for no reason whatsoever.  4. conclusion Yes, shooting nazis robots and evil technology IS fun. But this fun is limitted dramatically by the heavy amount of flaws that this game has. I am glad that people are willing to return the old-school genre to its former glory, but never mind what all the reviewers out there said, this Wolfenstein installment fails to do so properly. It is my sincerest hope, however, that the MachineGames will have a second try, because this franchise deserves its place in gaming history AND future! But the current effort is simply lacking.  If you want a good modern old-school game, buy Shadow Warrior.

I noticed that many of the reviews here were written before the authors finished the game. I would be singing the same tune as most of these people, but the latter third of the game is nothing but a disappointment.   The developers definitely tried to instill a bit of personality into BJ, our protagonist. He's no longer the hunk of nothingness from the prior games. BJ is now a thoughtful human being. Not a critical moment passes without an internal monologue delivered by him. These moments are a nice touch. His supporting cast is also decent. Some of the characters are quite intriguing. Unfortunately, not much is done with most of these characters. While some are quickly killed before you get a chance to know them, others are cast aside and left with little to do towards the end of the game. Even the main antagonist was given this treatment. He's only seen in the first and last level.   Although the attempts to instill some humanity into the narrative is admirable, it's also heavy-handed at times. Too often is the player reminded of the protatgonist's predicaments. We understand that BJ is a man with a conscience, but he does not have to be in agnony throughout the entire game. The presence of a forced romantic subplot doesn't help. Their motivation for engaging in said romance is never explored. It just happens after a large body-count. Wolfenstein's story is one that's yearning for some subtlety. There's potential, but it's not quite there.   The level design is possibly the saving grace of this game. There's a fair balance of stealth and combat in the earlier levels, where the stealth routes felt natural, and stealth sections were even spaced between combat scenarios. However, the levels denegerate into sheer chaos in later levels. This would fine, but as the game advanced, the environments also became more bland. While earlier levels were located in interesting locations, like an asylum and a concentration camp, later levels predominately took place in the interiors of generic military structures. Additionally, the officers that you must eliminate to prevent the arrival of reinforcements don't have much of a presence in said later levels, taking away a layer of depth that the game desperately needs.   Wolfenstein is a game that I really wanted to like. The developers definitely tried to reinvent the franchise with a more human and personable story, but between the ham-fisted dialogue and the amount of missed potential, I can't recommend Wolfenstein. It would be a fine game to pick up when it's on sale, but not for full price.

There are parts of this game that are embaressing to witness. What do I mean by embaressing? Well, you know how it's kind of embaressing to witness a strangers emotional outburst? Like if some guy and girl are all arguing in the parking lot of a restaurant, all crying, emotionally panting, and you have to walk by them? That's because they are strangers. You have no idea whats going on or what their motivations are or if you should say or do something. It's embaressing because you have no relationship with them what-so-ever. Guess what: the characters in this game are total strangers and the lack of any development therein makes witnessing their stories simply embarrassing... uninteresting... pitiful... horrible... etcetera. But there is a way to fix this of course: make the ♥♥♥♥ing game longer so that all the characters (that you are supposed to care about) are involved with you in some way. Hell, even the obligatory sex scenes are more embarrasing than sexy.  Third off: it's a pretty game. I bought a new PC to manage the pressure of this thing at the highest levels of complexity and I was not let down in that regard. The environments are interesting, the special effects are bloomtastic, and the modelling is (at the very least) exquisite.  Finally, there is no multiplayer game play. Let me sat that again: FINALLY AND MOST IMPORTANTLY THIS ♥♥♥♥ VARIENT OF RETURN TO CASTLE WOLFENSTEIN, ONE OF THE MOST GROUNDBREAKING MULTIPLAYER GAMES SINCE MULTIPLAYER GAMES WERE INVENTED, HAS NO MULTIPLAYER GAME PLAY. I can't think of anything more condemning than that. I mean seriously... what the ♥♥♥♥?  All told not even the prettiest flower is worth the cost of this game. It's mildly entertaining, but it's short and far to easy even at the hardest difficulty level. Buy it when it's far cheaper that a Denny's breakfast plate... at least breakfast at Denny's is a bit more entertaining.

I am honestly completely flabbergasted as to how this could be reviewed so positively. The storage requirements are ENORMOUS (a whopping 40+ GB), yet the optimization is garbage and the advanced customization options are junk; you can't even turn off the absurdly-overactive depth of field crap via in-menus, only turn it DOWN. The story is a thoroughly-bland waste of effort and time, and the game frequently has you doing inane, boring garbage like looking around a safehouse to find a stupid folder so you can get to the rest of the game.  As for the gameplay itself, well, it's HORRIBLY antiquated and plain. Enemy variety is poor, consisting of a very small handful of units you see repeatedly with different skins. The weapons selection is very meager (pistol, automatic rifle, shotgun, sniper rifle, and a cutting tool), and the weapons themselves very unsatisfying; enjoy unloading entire magazines into the heads of some 'armored' (even though they're wearing the same helmet as anyone else) enemies while they simply stand there and shoot you to pieces, never mind the 30-40 bullets slamming into their faces. Enemies are consistently damage sinks, so you spend most of the game firing far too much to kill many of the enemies; I actually thought I was playing a couple of 'boss' fights the wrong way, when it turns out there was no strategy at all involved other than 'shoot a lot more than is at all fun'. The 'overcharge' mechanic is worthless; extra health fades so rapidly as to last literally SECONDS, so the mechanic is completely pointless unless you spend most of your time standing on health packs. And you know when games make the INCREDIBLY crappy decision to take away all of your weapons and ammo? Happens. All. The. Freaking. Time. So you spend the majority of the game trying to get back all of the weaponry you've already acquired several times, often with absolutely no explanation as to why you are now mostly unarmed. The environmental destruction is also very minimal, with the most 'impressive' examples being a few short concrete hallways. The stealth gameplay is quite decent for an FPS, but the biggest motivation for using it is so you don't have to chew your way through more toe-to-toe combat; trying to avoid crappy gameplay by using mediocre gameplay isn't very fun, especially when you WANT to be shooting up a bunch of Nazis. The story is so bland and uninteresting that I've basically been just avoiding it completely for the last several hours. War is bad, Nazis are bad, killing is bad, yada yada yada. Boring. I honestly can't name a single character, and couldn't care less who lives or dies; I cannot fathom who thought it would be a good idea to shackle a Wolfenstein game to some 'deep' story about loss and war, but they were wrong and failed at the execution. Even the 'climactic' final boss fight is AMAZINGLY uncreative and tedious; it ends up being nothing more than a race to dump damage into the boss before it kills you, because you get stuck in a room with hellishly-bad cover. You end up spending the whole fighting running from health pack to health pack, with zero complexity or style to the fight other than 'shoot a thousand more bullets'.  Basically, the game is a massive grind. They even managed to make killing Nazis on the Moon incredibly tedious! You get shackled to battery-powered weapons, so if you aren't picking up batteries from EVERY enemy you kill (which is rather problematic since you want enemies to be dead far away from you, BEFORE they get close enough for you to grab batteries off them), you end up constantly having to charge off of wall outlets. Yes. Wall outlets. To charge guns. In the middle of combat. So you can shoot Nazis on the Moon.  Honestly, I forced myself to complete this game just so I could delete this bloated waste of time from my hard drive. Even at the $15 I got it for, this is one seriously tedious and uninteresting game. The music is probably the best part, but I would've been much better off just buying the music than playing this game. I would rather just play the original Wolfenstein than this game, because at least that one has the excuse of being more than 20 years old as a reason for being overly simplistic and repetitive.
