PLEASE READ MY FULL REVIEW BEFORE RATING THIS ONE! Thanks.  I'm a big fan of older id games. Heck, I even enjoyed Doom 3 and Quake 4. But I'm not a fan of Wolfenstein TNO. All its annoyances aggregate into a less than stellar experience.   What's the good? Gunplay is solid. Players can dual wield nearly every weapon. This is handy at higher difficulties since even the weakest enemies take a dozen rounds to drop. Also, guns have alternate fire modes. Although players will have access to all weapons early on, most of the alt modes are not unlocked until later in the game. This breaks up the monotony and balances the game a bit.   The campaign lasts about 15 hours. For a $60 title with no multiplayer, that's the minimum I'd expect. The environments are varied and allow for slight amounts of exploration. So levels feel bigger than what they are. Players can employ different tactics to dispatch enemies. Stealth can be more effective than run and gun at times. And sometimes camping behind a box and popping baddies one by one is most effective. No style dominates the game. At the hardest difficulties, run and gun is least effective. However, after a single playthrough I noticed stealth is broken. Patrols will walk over dead bodies and not sound the alarm. They will only sound the alarm if they see the player or see him kill someone. So there is no need to drop baddies out of sight. Not very challenging.   What's the bad? The game is buggy. During cutscenes, audio and mouth movements don't sync (think Skyrim) breaking the emersion. Turning off Vsync sometimes helps, but then there is horrible screen tearing to deal with. Also, the game randomly freezes briefly at set intervals during the first few missions. The freezing magically stopped after progressing further. Using a controller presents other problems due to inconsistent button behavior. I select alt fire mode, and the map opens. I open the radial and select a weapon, my character briefly freezes while taking damage before the next weapon is available. Under normal circumstances that's annoying. While playing the hardest difficulty it's downright rage inducing.   The graphics are OK but not a great showcase for the id tech 5 engine. Wolfenstein is plagued with inconsistent textures, pop ins, and jagged edges. Lighting effects drastically change by moving an inch. And there are limited advanced graphic options. There is no AA control. The frame rate is locked at 60fps. Currently, SLI and Crossfire performance stinks. Forcing features thru CCC did not help. Another negative: Wolfenstein is a 50gb install. Plus, a huge patch has to be downloaded. Since the graphics and sound are merely OK, the size is just excessive. Here's a bit of irony: TNO looks like it was made using the Unreal Engine with its almost cartoony/almost cel shaded environments and weapons. Artistically, it looks like any recent Unreal-based games. Was this intentional?   I hate TNO's erratic pacing. Between missions, the player hangs out at a base. And the 'errands' between missions slow the game to a crawl. Forget about annihilating Nazis around the clock, because the resistance wants you to stop and find mold samples. Kill a few more Nazis and you're stopped again to find a blowtorch. The base and accompanying side missions mimic Dishonored. But this is Wolfenstein....  Lastly, I don't like the story. TNO tries too hard. It felt forced. It felt déjà vu. And the ending was just plain lazy. The aforementioned base exists solely to advance the story, but kills the action as a result. Heck, audio logs appear just for progressing through the game. No need to find em. And TNO holds players' hands thru everything. Someone is always on the radio detailing each step. And when 'map updated' appears on screen, 'secret' items are revealed on the map with a question mark. Too easy. Too pandering.   Sigh. Overall, TNO feels like a tacky homage. I'm annoyed that one of the final battles was ripped directly from Quake 4. Plus, TNO lacks the brutal combat and creativity of the games that made id synonymous with the fps genre. The new developers tried unsuccessfully to create an emotional backdrop instead of focusing on Wolfenstein's most important trait: Gunplay carnage. I'm all for a good story, but TNO's story was so violent, so gory, and just so over the top that I stopped buying into it. How much damage can the main character withstand? There's a difference between badassdom and just plain ridiculous. By the game's end, I didn't have that, 'Oh yeah, come get you some' feeling like I did in Max Payne 3. Instead, I was glad it was over.   Wolfenstein TNO is an OK fps. Unfortunately, TNO assimilates elements from other popular games without creating its own identity. This is not the nonstop ride gamers expect. Even worse, it's a console port that needed months of polish before its PC launch. TNO still has performance issues weeks after launch. Asking 49,99€ for buggy title with no multiplayer is a tall order. Wait for this game to go on sale.

This game sucks. If you bought it hoping for an action-packed classic-Wolfenstein experience, prepare for disapointment. Even the opening cutscene sucked, because it was at about ten FPS. On a brand new card. Bethesda seems to like cutting backroom deals with Nvidia, because my brand-new AMD card, which can run Fallout 4 max-settings at 60 FPS, can barely handle this game. It's the same thing that happened with RAGE. It was made so it couldn't run on AMD systems, and it happened again here, and then again with Watch_Dogs. The gameplay isn't even all that great either.  It's not that it's bad, just stupid. You have enemies who can barely see you in stealth from about ten feet away, while those same enemies have superhuman reflexes and sight as soon as you break stealth. It's like they couldn't decide whether to make a stealth game or a classic shooter, and they wound up with the worst of each. The first rifle you get can fire semi-automatically and kicks ♥♥♥, while all the 60s era weapons are all-auto-all-the-time, with absolutely no justification whatsoever. Even the pistol is burst fire, but attaching a supressor turns it back. What. Why can't I use that without the supressor?  You keep no gear between levels, again with no justification. You can't even keep your ammo. Good luck playing this game like a real shooter. It's a stealth game advertised as a shooter. Duel-wielding? Forget it, useless. And because of the atrocious performance, forget aiming. In a game with no true semi-auto guns and no way to get rid of the lag, you need something like that. This is a game where you can dual-wield shotguns and kill Moon Nazis.   This is probably the highest profile single-player FPS in quite some time. It was advertised as an old-school run-and-gun game much like Painkiller or Doom, but it's actually closer to playing like Half-Life 1 and 2. You progress through linear levels that you can either take stealthily or Rambo-style. The graphics look nice, although the colors seem a bit muted and there is no option for anti-aliasing. The game is fairly well optimized and runs at a pretty smooth frame rate even on low end machines.  The storyline plays out like a mix between Inglourious Basterds and Iron Sky. In this universe, the Nazis won World War II and have taken over the world. You play as BJ Blaskowicz as he wakes up from a coma in 1960 and joins the resistance. There are newspaper clippings all over the game detailing the history of this alternate world, and you get a few Easter eggs like a record by 'Die Kaefer,' titled 'Das Blue U-Boot.'   This isn't an easy game by any means. I died a fair amount on medium difficulty. The game uses a hybrid of old-school health packs and modern regenerating health. Armor does not regenerate but health will regenerate to the nearest multiple of 10 (if you get shot so your health is 75, it will regenerate to 80 but not more) and you can overcharge health for those reckless guns-blazing sections where you know you are going to take more damage than normal, but the overcharge will eventually level out to your maximum health. This means there are equal amounts of balls-to-the wall corridor shooting sections and large open stop-and-pop arenas. It feels like a merger of both 90's and 2010's FPS design philosophy. You are encouraged to search the whole level to find secrets, like gold, enigma codes, and health upgrades.   This is a story-based single-player game, so there is no multiplayer. There are currently no expansions or DLC's. What you pay for is the full, complete finished game. It feels like a breather from a market saturated with $60 games that only feel about 60% complete without DLC.   I would recommend this if you want to shoot Moon Nazis in the face with a laser cannon.
You get to shoot Nazis on the moon while dual-weilding lazer rifles. You also get to shoot armour-plated Nazi attack dogs while dual-weilding automatic shotguns. 11/10.

One of my top games of 2014, no doubt. The gunplay is excellent, with the ability to dual wield almost every weapon except for the Laser Kraftwerk (my favourite weapon in the game) and any turrets you can carry around. The gameplay is solid as well, with four different 'perk trees' to upgrade by completing challenges. Each tree is different, ranging from stealth gameplay to demolitions for those who like to run and gun. The bosses were fairly fun, although certain bosses was disappointingly easier than I expected. Overal the game is a great new installment to the Wolfenstein franchise and is perfect for those who want more old-school shooters and for those (like myself) who love the idea of alternate history and history all together.   TL;DR Version:  Pros: -Great graphics and framerate (on my PC, not certain about others) -Excellent gunplay -Variable gameplay -Awesome setpieces and level variety  Cons: -Some bosses easy while others are a good challenge  Overall rating: 9.5 Nazi Skulls out of 10 Recommended to: Shooter fans, history buffs, and those who crave old school nostalgia

A Quick Review - A Shooter With A Soul and a Story. Well, I must say I really enjoyed the game. I played the original and the various iterations of the shooter genre since, and none of them had the heart this game does. All the characters are very well drawn and presented as powerfully and a realistically as any I have ever played. If you are a person who prefers to focus on the game solely as an exercise in trigger pulling this may not matter to you, but I was amazed at the quality of the writing and the character development. It is the best writing I’ve experienced in any game, and the main character in particular has a compelling inner dialog and a broad personl scope of the sort you’d normally find in a movie.   The game also does a wonderful job of defining the ideas and methods of the Nazis and it does it in a way that does not interfere with game play – you hear snippets of conversations for instance, and they are chilling. You truly get a sense of the stakes and the sacrifice that is needed to stop them. Again, rather than slap together another tired shooter the people behind this game made it all very personal and human, and went to great effort to produce a cast that meant something. Great heroes, great villains. There is a mountain of carnage and gunplay along the way, horror and stomach churning moments, set pieces with massive scale and excellent cinematics, and a world that is well composed and frightening. All of the voice acting is stellar.  I strongly recommend turning on all the subtitles and allowing the personal and emotional parts of the game to play out if you want to understand what this game was supposed to be – not just a shooter, but a story about people fighting to save the world. Wolfenstein is really a tribute to those in uniform and what they choose to give up to defeat evil. And you do get to kill a lot of Nazis. It is not perfect, but it definitely is one of the few games I liked so much I wrote a review.  In the end it is not a simply “shooter”. It is a game about waging war. If you let the dialog and story work you will find a lot to like. The effort was successfully made to convey an understanding of why you’re fighting and make you care about the outcome and the main character. I recommend it.

I bought this game during the Steam Holiday sale. I bought it literally on just the 'Nowhere to run' trailer. Even from that video alone, it's clear that Wolfenstein: The New Order isn't just some thrown together game that you're going to get bored with a forget 5 minutes after you finish. In a word, this game is all about polish. Almost every aspect of the game feels carefully crafted to make a very memorable experience.  First of all, the guns. There's not many of them, but each is fun to use. Also, as you've probably heard, almost every gun can be dual-weld. If you're looking to blaze down a hall dual-weilding auto shotguns, this is the game for you. The gunplay is incredibly satisfying as well.  Second are the characters. In a game that's about mindlessly mowing down Nazis, you wouldn't expect characters that you'll actually care about. But this game has exactly that. There's great dialog and some thought out character development that keeps you invested throughout.  Third is the music. Just the fact that I'm devoting a paragraph to the music alone should tell you how much I loved it. It'll have your head nodding when you're deep in battle, with loud, almost industrial techno. It's soft and thoughtful when the game slows down. It perfectly fits with the theme of battling through a distopia, with lots of high octane action. The soundtrack is on Spotify as well. Definitely check that out.  Lastly, I feel this game needs to be praised most for its pacing. This is an aspect of games I feel like a lot of people don't even discuss. I think this is mostly due to the fact that people expect games and levels within games to be long nowadays. This is presumably due to the notion that if something is long, you're getting more value. However when you play a well paced game like this, you realize this isn't always the case. The game is smart enough to shift between between the action, stealth, time in HQ, and cutscenes at such a fast pace, that it never feels dull for a moment. Because of this, I found myself playing for longer sessions than I normally do. Just when things are about to get dull, a giant Nazi robot will probably attack. Just when you're probably about to get burnt out from too much shooting, the game is probably just about to slow down for dialog. I really wish a lot more games tried harder to achieve good pacing, as it really makes the entire game much more enjoyable. It allows you to experience pieces of the game in enjoyable bursts, rather than dragging on to the point of boredom.  All in all, I can't really see this game disappointing any fan of shooters of action games in general. Unless over the top gore isn't your thing, absolutely play this.

Wolfenstein: The New Order is an excellent single player FPS. The game takes place during an alternate history in which the Nazis win World War II. You play as Capt. William Joseph 'B.J.' Blazkowicz, an American soldier and member of the resistance movement. I don't want to say anymore about the story for fear of spoilers, but there are some good plot twists and it has a good pace throughout the game.   The guns in this game feel like they have a lot of power. It's especially satisfying to dual wield shotguns and decimate everything in the room. You also have option of playing stealthy (at first). If you are revealed, you can't return to stealth like in some games. This isn't necessarily a bad thing though -- like I said, the guns in this game are very satisfying to shoot.   Lastly, I really like the effort that this game puts into the alternate history. Besides the Nazis winning World War II, you can find little snippets of news articles about monumental events (such as Nazi Germany being the first country to land on the moon).   Overall, Wolfenstein: The New Order is a great, action-packed game.

This is a blast of a game to play. I particularly enjoy the ramping up of the missions B.J. has to complete. Almost a situation of 'Aw, crap, are you kidding me? I gotta go and do WHAT now?' The mental challenges of the storyline are pretty well set in place and provide good motivation to keep after the goals.   The only unfortunate issue I have is that the movies between missions don't keep up with the audio very well. I don't know how common this is, but the three options in dealing with the matter are down to, let the video drag on until it gets to where the audio ended almost a minute ago, or hit escape a couple times quickly to get it to synch to the current spot in the video, only to have the audio run off into the distance again. The third option is just to skip the movies altogether by hitting E until it picks up on the next mission. This destroys the gameplay and especially for the first few times through. After a few runs on easy it doesn't bug me as much, but it's still a bit of a letdown.  As to the movie content, it's top notch. I'm not a fan of sex scenes in video games in general due to the fact that they are rarely pertinent to the game itself. I'm marginal on whether this game needed one, but at the same time it was tastefully done, and did contribute to setting the emotional tone of what the storyline is all about, so no complaints.   the weapon selection is a bit clumsy in arrangement, but getting used to it will happen. Maybe displaying the number key each weapon is assigned to when you thumb the scroll wheel on the mouse would help make things more fluid. The weapons themselves are pretty well designed and execution is good too.   Finally, I know this game isn't new, but it has aged pretty well, all things considered. I enjoy a romp through the levels on a regular basis, and I doubt I'll be getting tired of it any time soon.  Well done ID Software, and thank you.

This is a fantastic addition to the series. The previous iteration by Raven Software was... bad. I have enjoyed the ability to choose whether I Rambo my way through the map dual weilding assault rifles, sneak through a hidden corridor to come up behind a commander and slit his throat, or a combination of the two. The graphics are great and will really shine on Ultra settings, provided you have the GPU to support it. There have been a few instances where the automatic weapons will have a stray shell casing stuck next to the gun, but this was a minor glitch.   One neat little gameplay element that I have enjoyed so far is the way the map is unlocked. Of course as you progress through the level, you reveal the places that you have been, but say you find an emergency exit map on the wall... pick it up and you reveal the entire location. It was a subtle gameplay presentation that I really enjoyed; however, I can see this getting redundant and losing its appeal over time.   In past reviews, other players have reccommended starting on Hard difficulty for experienced FPS players and I agree. I usually start on Normal difficulty on all games just to get a feel for it before I crank it up on a second playthrough. In this case, I started on Hard and have not been disappointed. It definitely presents a challenge, but it is not overbearing so long as you take cover when necessary. The ammo and health are abundant between firefights and I'm often forced to leave bullets behind due to max ammo cap. This, of course, could be due to my playstyle.   Overall, in the crowded genre of FPS, this game does not introduce any gamechanging mechanics. The story is well written, the graphics are great, and the gameplay is solid. The lack of multiplayer may decrease the replay value, but some games just don't need it. While a co-operative campaign would have been a good addition, it would not have fit with the story, and a hastily thrown together adversarial multiplayer would have detracted from the overall experience.

A thoughtful take on single-player first person shooters. A number of the team worked on the Riddick games for Xbox. Like Riddick, an emphasis on mature story telling result in something that could have been dragged down by an admittedly silly premise. Based on id tech 5, the shooting and movement are snappy, precise. Uh, I liked it.

What makes the gameplay brilliant is that it contains classic concepts alongside more modern: eg non-regenerating health and rediculous weapons + more modern duck/cover mechanics. The story is clever story that is very  very  un-call-of-duty. It had a feel to the story that isn't really classic per say but just different, something very refreshing in the age of cod, they put as much work into the game as possible, it isn't some cash grab.  Graphics wern't as awe inspiring as Crysis 3 or Battlefield 4 but they were pretty decent. I ran this game on a 4-core i5 and an AMD 7850 and I got good framrates and I was running it on the highest settings. The graphics are a lot better then Rage (which uses the same engine) and I really thought some the sceenery is excellent. And it has excellent coloring so you don't get the cod-esk gray-ish lighting in places that should be colorful. Right now a lot of games that have come out recently are colorless souless cash-grabs that flood the mainstreem, this is as far from that as possible.  Over all It is an excellent game, is it as good as or better then Half-Life 2, probably not. But it is different, so many games are just a cash-grab that is the same as the last one because they are affraid to change it to make it better. This game isn't like that, they put every ounce of work into it. They wern't trying to get it out the door as fast as possible, they wanted to make what came out as good as possible.  Some parts of the game kind of seemed out of place, such as the side quests and the unlocking system (don't worry, you barely notice anyways.) but what they did with this game was wonderful. I can only hope that Doom 4 has some of these people working on it, they know how to do quality.  If you are tired of Call of Duty, grey, some-old gameplay, story that is as boring as a lump of clay get this. This game proves that not only is iD still alive as a company but that maybe the first person shooter genre is as well.

A great old-fashioned shooter. 10/10  Beautiful environments and intelligent design make this game a breath of fresh air after a decade of shooters geared towards 'realism' rather than 'escapism'.    Gameplay   Weapons are designed to fulfill a function rather than to give variety within a class of weapon. Enemies are not bullet sponges, but use cover intelligently and flank relentlessly. The game encourages stealth rather than imposing upon the player an entire stealth section. To this end, it becomes beautifully integrated into gameplay and becomes a real aid rather than a gimmick.  However, choosing from multiple weapons in combat is clunky and could stand to go the half-life route.  Level design is vicarious and not utilitarian. They make sense. The prison looks like a prison, feels like a prison, so-on and so-forth. Any onlooker can easily tell you where you are in the scheme of things., There are multiple avenues of approach that are not readily apparent. Caches of first-aid kits, armour and ammunition are placed nicely.  Also, no regenerate back to full-health nonsense. When you're in trouble, you're in trouble.   Story   BJ encounters his arch-nemesis. A being capable of great cruelty that no one can ignore, even sub-consciously. He gets gravely inured and ends up in hospital. He awakens 14 years later from a vegatative state to defend his nurse from Nazis.  He then joins the resistance and aids them to great effect. The end-goal being revenge and justice for those lost.  While the plot is simple, the motivation has real substance. The antagonists are true totalitarian monsters and yet the supporting cast makes the player question the protaganist's character. Is he prejudiced ? Is he truly just when he kills the enemy ? Does he do his work unthinkingly ? Is he a monster for killing so viscerally and with hate ?  It leaves the player with a lot of questions, allowing him to make his own decisions as to how he views BJ. It's suprisingly mature.  It is perhaps most apt, that whatever the player takes away from this experience will depend on how invested in the plot he really is. Just following and not thinking about the game will certainly lead one to conclude that this is just another shooter. There is a story with very strong characterisaction, but only to those who take it.  It is with sad irony that I note the many straight-faced comments where people admit they don't understand the extremely simple plot and yet say the story is bad. They then go on to make excuses saying they only noticed the killing of Nazis. It's as if no one even knows enough to give a brief overview.  I have one major criticism despite the praise I have for the unflinchingly simple plot and excellent characterisation. The game resorts to heavy-handed gesturing to motivate the player at times. It likes to impose upon the player a feeling of helplessness and then quickly alleviate the situation. This confuses me. If it intends to characterise oppression, it is excellent. But if it doesn't, it's simply a machine to move the plot along.   Sound Design  The game has a great soundtrack and various perfectly-timed music cues. Weapons sound appropiately meaty and certainly change with distance and environment. Accents I cannot judge, I do not live in Europe. But I find them lovingly protrayed. NPC barks and the little conversations they have are enlightening and not at all useless.  I love how this game sounds.   Conclusion  Worth 60 dollars. Eagerly awaiting the sequel.

I hesitated to go back to Wolfenstein after the last outing that Raven Software put together, I do rate Raven software for many things, like COD map packs and their excellent single player games like Quake 4 and Singualrity.  The last Wolfenstein, aptly titled Wolfenstein was a run on rails shooter with almost zero storyline. All the hype and screenshots made it look great, only...it wasn't. Plus it had a tacked on multi player that made Wolf:ET fans shudder at its mention.   Now I say all that so that you know how cautious I was about going into this version of Wolfenstein, further more it's set in an alternative timeline where the Nazi regime has defeated the Allies and the whole world bows to the Reich. It's years on into the occupation of the Americas and Europe and this is where we are greeted by a familar old face. Enter BJ Blascowitz.  Now I won't say too much about the storyline and instead focus on what you get from this new title in the franchise. Machine Games have developed Wolfenstein their own way, which meant NO Multiplayer, though I'm still hopeful that Paul Wedgewood and his team at Splash Damage will revisit the franchise and re-do Wolf:ET later in the future. This single player adventure is fantastic. It's part movie and all FPS at the same time. The graphic details of the carefully crafted levels are a sight to behold, never has so much thought gone into the level design in a Wolfenstein title, it's gorgeous. The gameplay mechanics are easy to pick up and the gun play is filled with gibs galore.   This is a perfect continuation of the franchise, set apart by the timeline difference our Nazis are still Nazis and the tech is somewhat analog and plausible. I am loving the storyline and the characters that Machine Games have put together, the storytelling allows events to unfold as they're meant to without the rough crooked jump cuts from a Call of Duty single player.   In closing this is a must have single player for Wolfenstein fans, it's my top pick for 2014 single player titles next to Dying Light.

Gameplay  First and foremost, I'll start with gameplay, as that's often what's most important. As far as gameplay goes, Wolfenstein, for me, was like a blast from the past in terms of how the shooter played out, and felt between the level design, health system, and so on. Allowing overcharge of health like in the old dooms, as well as the pickups of armor, it really felt nostalgic. But then they upped it, allowing you to for example remove armor pieces/helmets from nazis/machines, and wear those. Health can come from food as with the other wolfenstein games. Level structure felt a lot like Return to Castle Wolfenstien; linear, but open enough to explore/find secrets, which was a very good thing.  The shooting itself was great, though I found the dual wielding a bit unwieldy; couldn't zoom in without switching off dual wielding, and often times you just didn't have the health/armor to really make use of it unless using some SERIOUSLY heavy weaponry. Generally I found myself preferring the single gun setup.  The stealth system was neat because it wasn't needed at all, but encouraged. You could take out enemy 'commanders' to silence reinforcement calls if you did it stealthily; doing so also makes a lot of the secrets show up on the map, allowing you to find them easier. (they appear as ? marks, so it's not exact where they are, just the general area. Easy to figure out, but not an exact give-away).  A few negative aspects were sometimes with bosses it was a lot of trial and error; it wasn't wholly clear how to beat a few of them without trying a few times, or surviving long enough to get some radio advice from npcs.  Overall the gameplay, levels, ect, was over the tops and extremely fun. I enjoyed it thoroughly, and may play-through a second time, which is rare for me. As far as realism though; don't expect it. You're practically a superhero in terms of durability and agility.   Story  Despite being such an over-the-tops shooter, the story was surprisingly 'down to earth' in terms of moral, feeling, characters, and overall just narrative. It was very, VERY good; something somewhat rare in shooters, but a very good treat. The character's had good voice acting in my opinion, and overall made me feel attached/sad/joyed/excited and so on. The plot twists, enemies, all of it fit together in a splendid package, and the story was a rare treat as far as shooters, and games in general go.   Graphics/Sound  Generally I have no problems as far as sound goes, i'm not picky. In this, it was just as good. I would of liked if the bigger guns sounded as big as they looked, but that's excusable for me.  The graphics were not completely modernized, though had a consistant look in terms of textures/theming/ect, and overall they did the job they were meant to well enough, even if they were not top of the line.  On the downside, optimization was a big downfall in this one; the requirements are far higher then most games I've seen and the graphics didn't match up to most of them, as a result I'd say the optimization could use some work.   Overall/Extra  Overall I'd say this game was worth it; it was short, ten hours when I only got about half the secrets, and one playthrough; but for me, that's like going to the movies 5 times, for the price of 3 times. So I'd say it was worth the money given the story, gameplay, and entertainment value.  If you dislike short-ish games, don't care about story, or overall just don't like shooters, this isn't gonna change much for you, but it was a nice treat as far as shooters go, and if there is a sequal I'll surely be picking it up!

Not enough games center around killing Nazi Space scientists anymore, most games nowadays are unfortunately about demonising the Russians, which is just no fun.  And then comes The New Order, a fast paced, Nazi-murdering first person shoot-em-up, with a surprising amount of character in it.   The story, while not much to really write home about, does add some character to the protagonist BJ, making the relationships he forges with the other characters much more believable.  Anyway, the gameplay is the best thing about the game. As mentioned before, the game dumps you into a level with nothing but you and a ♥♥♥♥ton of Nazis between you and your objective. The levels have multiple routes, allowing you to stealth your way around if that's your thing. But sometimes, you just wanna kick the door down and wreak havoc, and the game gladly allows you to indulge in that playstyle. Each level grows in ludicracy to the point where the game takes you to the mother♥♥♥♥ing moon and back (literally), gradually building up to the final boss which will kick your ♥♥♥ many a time if you haven't played a game with an intense boss at the end for a while.  Now, no game is perfect, and The New Order certainly has it's flaws. For instance, the interludes between some missions in the Resistance HQ, while rich with lore and backstory concerning the world BJ lives in, notably slow the pace of the game and can be rather tedious after a particularly enjoyable mission. However, a semi-positive to this is, that these can be used as quitting points in the game if you don't want to lose track of what's happening in your mission.  Other than that, Wolfenstein: The New Order is one of the better FPS games of recent years and a breath of fresh air in the sea of modern warfare game that flood the market nowadays and earns a solid 9/10 from me. I sincerely hope anyone buying the game has as much fun as I did with it.  Have fun murdering those Nazis, you ♥♥♥♥ing Psycho!  -Boogles.

Overall, Wolfenstein: The New Order is an excellent example of what modern AAA shooters are lacking. The controls are tight, and armor and health systems add a sense of tension to the gameplay, and the weapons are unique and satisfying to use. This game has some major Half-life 2 themes, in terms of level design and puzzle solving. The story was engaging and interesting enough to keep me coming back to play it until it was done.  +Graphics and particle effects are beautiful +Gunplay and cover system is effective and feels nice +Story is engaging  +Lots of secrets and collectables +Stealth vs run-and-gun choices in levels +Enviroments vary and give each level its own feeling +Enemies are well balanced, and each offer their own challenge -Beefy requirements for max settings -No SLI support -Locked at 60fps for gameplay and 30fps for cutscenes -Some enviroment textures look like garbage -Some puzzles are repetitive and tiresome -Could utilize objective markers better (easy to get turned around) -The ending leaves a lot to be desired -Alternate story paths require full replay of the game, but lead to the same end. My favorite thing about this game had to be how well and professionally done the audio was. Robot's would have sweet guitar riffs. Boss's would have sweet heavy metal guitar riffs. There were guitar riffs everywhere that catalyzed my anger to kill Nazi's. My only let down has been a beef of mine for the last two games. Make a multiplayer like Enemy Territory. Some of the most fun I've had playing an FPS in years. I always appeciate a game in this genre that decide to focus just on singleplayer instead of multiplayer. The story, while not treading any new ground, is servicable and the characters are likable and believable. It's an alternate 1960 in which Nazi Germany won and now has crazy future tech to keep the population under their boot. The game takes you to many fun locations all over the world that look beautify ranging from Nazi Berlin, to under the sea in a U-Boat to a Nazi moon base! There is also a large perk system that both rewards you for your play style while incentivizing you to change up the way you play to explore all the ways you can approach situations.   Luckily, the game play is even better. The classic play with few modern additions are greatly apperciated by myself. Health only partial regenerates up to the closest multiple of 20 up to 100 HP and you can pick up armor points to supplement. Being able to carry all the weapons you find without having to give up a weapon is also classic. Each weapon has a secondary fire AND can be dual wielded. You can control the secondary mode of each dual-wielded weapon seperately which allows for easy use of both modes at the same time. You do lost the ability to aim down the sights, but they remain manageable as long as you don't fire in full auto except at close range. The hell you can unleash when nessarary is a blast.  Another surprise is the relatively fun stealth system. The AI isn't exactly the smartest about reacting to all the dead Nazis you leave in your wake, but it still is fun to sneak around stabbing unsuspecting Nazis. You can throw extra knives from a distance to silent kill from a distance. Remain in stealth when a commander is present keeps extra enemies reinforcements from coming. Going in hot will cause a constant stream of angry Nazis to show up until you manage to kill all present commanders.  If you are anything like me, wishing you could play another FPS that takes insperation from the games of 15 years ago instead of being another CoD shooter, you'll love this game. Totally worth couple playthroughs.

I expected this game to be an average shooter. When it was announced as being in development, I was only mildly curious, and as the release date approached, I wasn't excited. I probably made the decision to buy it because of the DOOM beta access.   Turns out, it is a very good game, with some of the best voice acting, mocap, and storytelling I have ever seen in a game. Some of the characters express ideas that you just never see in games, and rarely in cinema. Metaphysical naturalism, determinism, and nuanced religious musings are featured as optional character dialogue, and it fleshes out the characters and concepts on offer in an effective way. The ideas on offer in this game are thought-provoking and fresh, particularly when compared to other shooters.  I didn't understand the music at first, as the main motif didn't strike me as very Wolfenstein-ish, but as the game progressed, I discovered that the motif is intertwined with other themes, and the soundtrack as a whole made sense and was emotionally effective.  Sound effects are fantastic. Played with a decent pair of studio headphones. I'm sure it'd be amazing with a legit setup.  Gameplay and game systems are solid, but I wish I didn't have to farm for perks. There ought to be better ways to gain access to perks. They could also be more interesting. Perhaps you ought to be able to specialize, and be locked into a tree, but be rewarded accordingly, instead of having access to literally everything.  Overall, very good game. Nein/10.

Pleasant surprise. The new Wolfenstein is not only something much more than I expected, but an accomplishment in and of itself. From gorgeous visuals, imaginative alternate reality, colorful characters, to a complete disregard for the modern formula of shooter, Wolfenstein: The New Order steps up and beyond the plate of the standard FPS.  Being able to dual wield everything in the game is something I haven't seen in shooters since the world has come to accept realism as the best method for escapism. The moment you pull out two shotguns and fire an endless barrage of buckshot death towards towering robot Nazi soliders is the moment Wolfenstein has wooed you with its outrageousness. But absurdity alone cannot carry a game, which brings us to where the game truly shines. Despite the complete over-the-top design and gameplay, the story plays itself out completely straight. Despite many of the characters being nothing more than walking tropes, they're delivered in such a way that makes them endearing and engaging. The hulking, barrel chested protagonist himself consistently delivers a sense of humanity and at times, vulnerability. This combined with a complete overhaul of full throttle nonstop crazy shooting-fest delivers the motivation along with the killer gameplay. All this, and it's a mere single player shooter. Wolfenstein reminds us that the norm isn't necessarily the best and only approach to games, and reminds us of a time when outrageousness was championed genuinely.  I look forward the the future of gaming with MachineGames in it. They have much to offer in a time of homogenized oversaturated game formula.

Despite Jackal's crying and whining, I've decided to reconsider. After all, he does make a valid point, do I hold TNO above RAGE? Yes. However, its a game with serious flaws.  What you are getting is a story-centric first person shooter that focuses on tight, visceral gunplay, at the expense of really silly sections that they use to shake things up. The final boss is a perfect example of this, as it isn't really apparent how you need to kill him.   The story is quite good until you realize it boils down to 'war sucks' and the final cutscene failed to illicit any feels at all, unlike the recent Shadow Warrior. (C'mon...Hoji's speech was awesome. Best love story ever.) The charactors are all quite good, but there isn't much chance to flesh them out due to the breakneck pace of the story.  The weapons selection irritates me, but some people (Jackal) seem to think its acceptable. I just wanted TNO to have imaginative and interesting weapons. A Gravity gun, a Flak Cannon, a BFG, a Crossbow, etc etc. It boils down to basic counter strike style assault rifles and shotguns with the addition of dual wielding. Dual Wielding assault rifles with ♥♥♥♥ing rocket launchers attached is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome, but it doesn't feel remarkably different from other shooters.  The Perk system is quite good, killing 20 enemies while crouch sliding to get say faster reload, is cool and gives me incentives to play the game in a different style than I normally would.  The graphics are ♥♥♥♥ing outstanding, but you already know this. It took me around 16 hours to beat the game, so you will get a fair amount of play time if you are searching the nooks and crannys. I have not actually beaten the game, as I found the final boss pushed my patience, and the story didn't press me forward enough to keep trying. I watched the final cutscene ala youtube and thought it was pretty silly anyway.  This is a ♥♥♥♥ing great game, just be prepared for some frustration with the design decisions. Definately worth a purchase if you are into first person shooters.

Certainly the most thrilling entry in the series, Wolfenstein: The New Order fixes everything that was wrong with the previous, lackluster title. The controls are tight, and the levels are well-designed, despite being almost completely linear (there are often choices between sneaking through vents and confronting a horde of enemies directly). If you're a glutton for punishment, you can take on the Uber difficulty, which offers a great challenge. There's a seemingly-pointless perk system that adds little more than excuses for achievements, but it doesn't get in the way of gameplay.  The story is rich and engaging, with appropriately-gruesome cutscenes and narration. It's not a revolutionary FPS by any means, but you will definitely enjoy the time you spend with it.

I enjoyed pretty much everything in this game, and the Wolfenstein series is thoroughly reinvigorated with this solid entry. I am totally hoping for a sequel by the same team.  I had barely seen any trailers or any information for this game before playing it, and felt strangely rewarded for it, being gradually introduced to its compelling setting. (If you are similarly oblivious, stop reading now and just go play it.)  This game succeeds at transforming player stand-in B.J. Blazkowicz into an actual character this time around, with an actual story involving other well-written characters. The character models are very detailed and well-animated, and while some of the rest of the graphics are technically not quite top-notch, the atmosphere is rich and believable. The soundtrack enhances select scenes but generally stays subtle and never bothers the player.  The gameplay is satisfyingly and gratifyingly simple; SHOOT THE NAZIS. At easier difficulties, the game is mostly a pleasant frustration-free shooting gallery, but there are enough higher difficulties to challenge even hardcore gamers. There's also a good amount of meaningful choice; story choice with distinct effects, stealth vs assault, multiple routes etc., and the developers have done a good job at making all alternatives viable and balanced.  Still reading? Just go pick it up, especially if it's on sale for 20 usd or less (like now). Those Nazis aren't going to kill themselves.

Reviewing this game is an interesting challenge. There are so many good things about it. At the same time, there are some negatives but those same negatives make sense in the overall definition of the product.  At its core, Wolfenstien: The New Order (WNO) is an action hallway shooter. Make no mistake about it: this is not an open world or sandbox type shooter. This is hallway to hallway, room to room, type action. Its pretty much impossible to get lost and the game makes it obvious where you are to go next. The most important thing to understand about this game is that sets out to create an action experience. If you are looking for a product with RPG qualities or a big open world this might not be your game. One more note here: This is single player ONLY. Do not come into WNO looking for multiplayer.  Now with that out of the way... WNO is, overall, a great game in its genre. It has everything a person could want in an action shooter. The controls are great. The weapons 'feel' powerful and offer variety of choices. The enemies aren't completely useless and won't just run up to you so they can die. It is certainly an action game but you can't stand in the middle of a room, unguarded, and hope to come out alive. Additionally, the Nazis come in all shapes and sizes: big Nazis, small Nazis, robot Nazis, mecha Nazis, cyborg Nazis, crazy Nazis and finally, flamboyant Nazis.  Some of the best parts: This game may be an action shooter but the story line is genuinely good. You meet a lot of different, and well developed characters. You can feel the gravity of the situation at hand. This game does an incredible job of painting an alternate reality where the Nazis have taken over the world. I can't believe I am saying this, but the story is very good. I didn't expect ANYTHING out of the story and yet I found myself following along and listening to every line.  The gunplay is fantastic. All the weapons have 'punch' to them and the variety of weapon types is a big plus in terms of gameplay. You (as the main character) can choose to attack head on, use a sniper rifle, or duel wield just about every gun for maximum damage output. MY personal favorite was duel wielding assaut rilfes. Want to clear out that room? You will have a blast doing it. The boss fights are a lot of fun as well.  Some of the negatives... As I said in the opening, this is a hallway/room shooter. A part of me knows this was a concious design choice but I would love to see a bit more variety. You have to play the game the same way, every time. You can't choose alternate pathways or tackle a fortress in more than one way. The game forces you from room to room. Being a cinematic shooter, I get that. That said, a little more variety would not have been a bad thing.  The game also feels like it should have had more dialogue choices. The main character (you) makes ONE story choice and the game plays out around that choice. Don't be mistaken here: that choice only shapes a handful of lines by the characters. It actually has next to no effect on gameplay. There is some small bonus depending on your choice but it really doesn't matter. The goal here was trying to get the customer to play through the game twice.    Overall... I think WNO is a great game for its genre. I like using letter grades, so I give it a B+. (Its my way of saying this is very good, but not perfect.) If you enjoy FPS games and want a good story, with great action, this is your game. It truly is a well crafted product. If you want something else you may be better suited with an open world or RPG shooter.

Slick and polished. Well made FPS. Took me 20 hours to complete, took my time and enjoyed the details. Satisfying combat. The turret gun is fun...liquifies the enemy. B.J. Blaskowits is well done and likeable with a very likable demeanor. The game ran flawlessly for me at all maxed settings...including high spec adjustments via Nvidia Inspector. Not a single crash or problem, so I don't know why others have had issues...??? Nice weapon designs. Nice animations and characters. Good story too. Kinda high priced compared to much larger games like Dark Souls 2 which is HUGE and less money. But I have to say I have no complaints. It was worth it to play the game. Pretty good replay value too because there are two diferent time lines you can opt to take. Perhaps the only thing I might have desired more of in the game, was 1. A bit longer, especially perhaps the segment on the Moon, and 2., Perhaps a few more enemies, perhaps some Nazi 'creatures' / monsters...which I think would have fit right with the game.  Compared to the last game, 'return to castle Wolfenstein', it is a better game in most respects, however, I myself very much liked the 'occult' aspect, and since the Nazi's were in fact into the occult, I think it would have been pretty cool to have given some of that into this game too...???   Overall, the game is very well polished and exhibits nice design and attention to detail. The mechanical robot dogs made no sence to me though, because, it would be utterly stupid to create a robot dog whose weaponry were teeth like a dog, instead of some kind of lazer or energy weapon. The 'armored' dobermin dog, however, WAS well done and DID make sense. Advice : Play it on one of the top two difficulty settings, otherwise you won't really sweat much and thus you will not be subject to any type of immersive feeling which B.J. most certainly WOULD experience given the situations he gets into.  Final note : If your budget is tight, and, say, you can only afford to spend money on a single FPS game, I'd say it's FAR bettet than anything that's come out for a while. However, if, say, you want to get an immense amount of game for your money, wait for a sale and instead opt for Dark Souls 2...which is rediculously huge for the money. I bought both. I hope they make another one of these, the ending leaves it open for another instalment.  Also, I'd play it with keyboard and mouse. I tried playing it with my xbox controller and using a stick to control aim is utterly worthless. With a mouse you get utter precision and control.

I have never played any of the Wolfenstein games, so this review will be a first impression of the title.  I have only played it through once, I may play it a second time to see what can be different, as there appears to be choices of who to save, you can if you want to do it in stealth or full guns blazing. 'Enjoyable full guns blazing, but can regret it when you get overwelming Nazi's and machines, not really a bad thing though.'   STORY  The story is very good for an alternative history, having seen that my allies have failed to repel the Nazi's and they have won, made me feel like that some ♥♥♥ kicking is in order, save the people who live in fear of being test subjects and killed, but it is getting common with 'ONE MAN WILL FIGHT THE WHOLE ARMY/COUNTRY TO SAVE THE WORLD, AND ONLY YOU CAN DO IT' thing, but oh well, its still very much enjoyable.   GAMEPLAY  The gameplay feels very arcadey which kinds of ruins the story telling, which I have enjoyed from what I could pay atention from, you just mostly feel like shooting Nazi's and not listen to the story as much (or at all), which is a shame, the ending is good in my view, I would like to know if there is an alternative ending though.   SKILL TREE  Skills feel like that they are not needed at all, they just feel wasted, I focused mainly on stealthing the game, so that I don't have to worry about getting hoards of Nazi's after me, but as I got further into the game, stealth became very much useless and you are forced to shoot everything, even though I had unlocked nothing in dual wield or single wield, I was still able to kill those Nazi's with ease.   AI  AI, oh boy...the AI is very basic in a way, as I have had many times that Nazi's are staring right at me in stealth, and just walk past me with no sound of alarm, you can just see their face staring right at you, they do this 'is....someone,' and keeps walking, either the Nazi's have really bad eye sight or their helmet goggles have too much tint of black, another bad AI was when you do get spotted, you can hear the Nazi soldier raises his voice in supprise, but the other Nazi's don't take any notic of him, if you kill him before he finishes his line, the alarm wont be raised.   COLLECTABLES  The games collectables are easy to find once you have foudn the map in the level, which is very close by at the start, sometimes a bit later on, but the map will show you every tunnel and all the collectables to get, this does stop the fun of searching for them, but there are time that you have to find a certain item to be able to reach the next room, plus the enigma codes is something I think every fan of the Wolfenstein game would enjoy collecting, as if they solved the enigma they can unlock new modes and difficulty to the game, and I would most likely thing the very first Wolfenstein game.   VERDICT  Would I recommend this game to my friends? I would say that the fans would enjoy this game a lot, but for people who have not played the Wolfenstein games before, not as much, if they like arcadey feel to the game, then yes I would recommend this game to them.   RATING  8.5/10 + Fun Game + Lots of Action - Bad AI - Pointless Skill Tree

This game was a pleasant surprise. It was a great mix of run and gun and quieter sections. I played on the hardest difficulty and got a lot of stuff, and I completed the game in 36 hours.  The good part is, that if I wanted to, I could go back and replay it because depending who you choose to help near the beginning of your game, will determine which of two main paths you take for the rest of the game. I chose to help Fergus, so now I can go back and help Wyatt instead and play a slightly different path. The bad news, is I have had enough of the game, so I probably won't do that. One can only take so much of a single player shooter these days.  Overall, the game is good, the artwork is excellent and I really love the way the game mixes action with movie clips. You really feel invested in some characters and the environments look really gorgeous. I should add, that I really felt something at the end of the game too, which I didn't expect from this game.  Definitely worth checking out, and if you play on the easiest difficulty, and don't worry about trying to get every single item, you could probably finish this game in about 8-10 hours. A solid B-list action movie in video game form. I say this to its credit. The game is pretty entertaining throughout. It expertly manages to be serious enough to be engaging, but without taking itself TOO seriously. The gameplay is fast-paced and unrealistic, but the game is more engaging for it, because it never feels like it's wasting the player's time. The gameplay facilitates multiple playstyles, which is to say it allows the player to run-and-gun or take a more stealthy approach (to an extent, at least. Deus Ex this is not). The game has a decidedly simple premise (it's an alternate history where the Nazis won, so you have to take down the Nazis) so there's little dissonance between the game's narrative and its mechanics, which is refreshing. Wolfenstein doesn't really break any new ground, but it doesn't need to. It's not flawless, but it's a solid game and worth checking out if you find the game to be affordable.

This is a fantastic addition to the series. The previous iteration by Raven Software was... bad. I have enjoyed the ability to choose whether I Rambo my way through the map dual weilding assault rifles, sneak through a hidden corridor to come up behind a commander and slit his throat, or a combination of the two. The graphics are great and will really shine on Ultra settings, provided you have the GPU to support it. There have been a few instances where the automatic weapons will have a stray shell casing stuck next to the gun, but this was a minor glitch.   One neat little gameplay element that I have enjoyed so far is the way the map is unlocked. Of course as you progress through the level, you reveal the places that you have been, but say you find an emergency exit map on the wall... pick it up and you reveal the entire location. It was a subtle gameplay presentation that I really enjoyed; however, I can see this getting redundant and losing its appeal over time.   In past reviews, other players have reccommended starting on Hard difficulty for experienced FPS players and I agree. I usually start on Normal difficulty on all games just to get a feel for it before I crank it up on a second playthrough. In this case, I started on Hard and have not been disappointed. It definitely presents a challenge, but it is not overbearing so long as you take cover when necessary. The ammo and health are abundant between firefights and I'm often forced to leave bullets behind due to max ammo cap. This, of course, could be due to my playstyle.   Overall, in the crowded genre of FPS, this game does not introduce any gamechanging mechanics. The story is well written, the graphics are great, and the gameplay is solid. The lack of multiplayer may decrease the replay value, but some games just don't need it. While a co-operative campaign would have been a good addition, it would not have fit with the story, and a hastily thrown together adversarial multiplayer would have detracted from the overall experience.

It's a step in the right direction as far as modern shooters go. Overall gameplay is quite fun which, even in the highest difficulty, allows to adapt to whichever playstyle you prefer (If you're good enough), whether it be dashing around like a maniac with two rifles out, or sitting behind a corner and playing it like your typical whack-a-mole-shooter campaign. There's a fair emphasis on stealth options too, although it isn't always possible, and honestly, it just isn't as fun as straight up fighting. The maps are fairly decent as well, most are linear, but manage well enough at being varied and interesting enough to not feel like your typical 'slog your way to the next setpiece' scenario.  But even with a step taken in the right direction, the other leg is still stuck in the mud that is modern cinematic games, expect the gameplay to be broken apart by scripted sequences and storytelling segments, some of which are quite lengthy. They're cool if it's your thing, but for me, more than once I've been wondering when I'll get to stop mucking about in this train/hideout/labor camp/sewer/whatever and get back to shooting nazis, the emphasis on storytelling would be more tolerable if the plot didn't become atrocious halfway through. Not to mention gameplay mechanics such as a dodgy segemented health regen system which hardly seemed necessary, as there was more than enough health and armor items placed about the maps. Secrets were an afterthought, most collectables are just tucked in a corner while actual hidden areas are very scarce. Plus, anyone else sick of canned takedown animations that designers insist be in every game these days?  All in all, it's a fun, albeit short game. Twenty hours through both timelines getting everything, but they were enjoyable hours, for the most part.  TL;DR?  Shootin's fun. Plot's dumb. Worth picking up if on sale.  Also, why is this sucker 40 gigs?

Being a big fan of RAGE and its engine, I was really looking forward to this game. But it left me uneasy having bought it full price when it was released.  GOOD Story is excellent and it will make you emotionally invested. This is very welcome counter-balance to heavy FPS action. The story will never let you forget who you're fighting against. Sometimes it gets a bit overbearing, but there is plenty of jokes and funny references to go around.  BAD I reloaded RAGE just to make sure I was remembering this engine correctly. Unfortunately I was. This game is technically one BIG mess. It doesn't support anti-aliasing or anisotropic filtering. If you enable it in the console, your FPS will go into crawl. It is worth noting that RAGE supported all these essential PC features fine back in 2011.  UGLY Texture memory management is a joke and even with any of the latest graphics cards the game will look like it's from 2011 all over again. The ugly part is that even RAGE looked better back in 2011. Now in 2014, the same engine is used, but in far worse way than in 2011. That is utterly inexcusable. For example, none of the shortcomings of the original RAGE implementation were addressed, such as texture pop-in. If you're a PC owner, you will be disappointed as this game's graphics appears to be dumbed down due to the current 'next gen' consoles.    CONCLUSION Despite brilliant story line, believable acting and satisfying gaming action, it's the technical execution which ultimately brings it down on PC. You may have heard an advice from other reviewers to wait in order to get this game from 'bargain bin' and I concur.

Wolfenstein: The New Order has to be thee best FPS I've played to date and that's saying a lot from me. I've played them ever since the first FPS that ever came out under the same name and over the years I've gotten burned out from playing them. They started to lose their appeal well over 5+ years ago and they all had the exact same thing going for them save a few titles. I put down the genre for about 5 years now and I'm glad I looked into this one. The trailers had me hooked and I usually don't pay full price for a game and usually wait until it's on sale, but I had to try this one out as it looked to have way more depth than any of them I've played so far. Of course I'd be happy paying less than $60 for a game, but for me at least, this game was worth the money. I've gone through the story once so far and I plan on going back trough it again to see what I've missed. The game's timing felt well pacedand ended with enough play time in between. I'm the kind of person that gets turned off if the game drags on for too long and this one felt long enough, not too short, not too long. The AI is very well put together and at times it feels like a real challenge to get through. I will caveat that I played this on the difficult mode, not Uber, which will be my next run through. There were plenty of frustrating moments that felt like it was impossible, but once I finally made it past the almost hopeless challenge of getting bombarded with heavy armament, I felt victorius. Wolfenstein never had much going for it when it came to story, and that's completely the truth for its first few iterations, however this time around I felt involved, intruigued and wanted to know all I could about the hero and his companions. I would definitely recommend this title to anyone who even just likes FPS's as this one feels fresh, keeps you hooked with its story and definitely pays off in the end when you get to murder every last one of the Nazi scum. I commend every developer, storywriter, artist, director and producer that provided such a fantastic piece of art. Job well done to all!

PROS:  -high production values -solid level design (It has arena-style locations, not just a series of tunnels.) -good mix of stealth and combat  CONS:  -poor save placement (For instance, it auto saves before you gather supplies throughout a level to face a boss. This is a difficult game to recommend, but I feel I must. It's ultimately, just a miserable game. I don't know quite how else to describe it. Obviously with the Nazi setting, it would have been inappropriate to make it a fun romp, but I came away from the game quite disheartened by it. Technically it's very good. Realistic graphics and great action set pieces, but the game world is just too grey. I suppose it makes a change from the 'realistic is brown' trope, but no matter where you are, everything is grey. They even try to justify it in the storyline in a subplot about concrete that never really goes anywhere. The action is good, but tends to swing from either annoyingly easy to frustratingly difficult several times through each level. You either have an abundance of health, armour and ammo, or you have to scratch your way through. Very rarely is there any middle ground, so you'll either stick with one gun throughout the game, or just throw everything you have at the baddies. There doesn't really seem to be a lot of point in some of the weapons, especially the shotgun. The biggest criticism I have about the game though is that it is just too miserable and frankly the ending sucks. When I finished the game, I felt no real sense of accomplishment. The final boss battle relies too much on good luck rather than skill to make you feel like you've really 'won' and the payoff to the storyline is a despressing as anything else. There is a plucky Scottish ally who adds some comic relief, but it's few and far between. Halfway through the game he has a breakdown, so you even lose that. There are two branches to the game which change the storyline slightly depending on which choice you make in an early level, but to be frank I don't really feel like I want to even bother with the second path. It just seems like a chore. And forget about trying on a harder difficulty, I can't imagine that'll be much fun at all; just frustrating. Ultimately a good game that needed some lighter moments, a better ending and a bit more colour.  Pros: Good storyline Realistic graphics and effects Fun gunplay  Cons: Too damn miserable I hope you like grey Weirdly balanced gameplay

AW-some!!! Just finished my first play through and enjoyed nearly every second.  First this is a huge install 50 GB and is built on the ID 5 engine used for the game RAGE.  So the visuals are fantastic.  The game starts during WWII and you are in a squad tasked to kill a Nazi codenamed DEATHSHEAD. He is a true evil genius. He is making cybernetic Nazi super soldiers and winning the war revolves around stopping him. You and your team are shot down durring your bombing run and must make the raid on foot.  Characters are developed as you go and the two that stands out are a duo that act more like father and son than veteran and grunt.   Quickly things go from bad to worse and soon you are captured. The villian enters and forces you to make a choice between the two I just mentioned, the one you choose will die a most gruesome death- while the other is left with you- locked in a cell- that soon will be and oven- to die.  This makes two character 'time lines' depending on who you choose- the story may develope in very diffrent ways...  As you escape you are caught in an explosion and catch a chunk of shrapnel in the head... (thats gotta suck) Cut scene- credits- Game truely begins.  You wake 15 years later in a family run mental hospital.... (' I don't know... It has always been my dream to open a nice little country psych ward were the troubled people of my country can come to get help, and terrorize my children.') - IDK  Anyway, the daughter has taken care of you and grown fond of you as you watch time pass in voice- overed cut scenes. You learn that the hospital is where the Nazis come to get test subjects and when they shut it down one day all Hell breaks loose and you are given control once again.  One of the coolest things are knife takedowns. You have to sneak up behind a Nazi and hit the 'takedown' key. (Some very brutal kills) One you actually slash the legs of the Nazi causing him to fall backward where you then perforate him chest several times. You get a gut reaction of 'ouch'  Some of the K-9 unit kills are viceral too.  The whole world has fallen under Nazi rule and is now the new norm. It now is your job to undo it. The game awards you with new guns now and then giving you the means to 'upgrade' them. Usually with a scope or a new ammo type. The gun mechanics are very standard and even with the ability to duel wield- I hardly ever did. Only a couple times did I even HAVE to. I played on normal difficulty. The story was simple and to the point with very little attempts to deepen the plot or character development.  This may be my lack of finding the right cues or skipping them because of choices I had made. Make sure you achieve all the goals in whatever chapter you are in once the plot moves along all side missions and hidden objects dissappear.  You can find hidden things throughout the game: glod objects, enigma codes, letters, newpaper clippings etc... that help to 'fleshout' the world but not much. You can decipher the codes to get unlocks but I haven't tryed yet so I haven't a clue on what they are about.  Like I said I enjoyed this game. Worth 60 bucks to me and that is saying something.  I will play through again choosing the other timeline so see if it differs. -GrAnD  **********************************************UPDATE********************************************************  Just finnished the second play through choosing the other timeline. The only real change I saw was a secondary character swap, one being a mentally broken woman that goes out in a blaze of glory and the other a man who may have been Jimmy Hendrix..... Still a fun game both times but I would have combined the two story lines and added content. I did notice this time they left the end open for more gameplay....  I hope they do!! -GrAnD

A game that somehow manages to be completely ridiculous and have an incredibly powerful and interesting story at the same time. The story really is the best part of the game, the way it focuses much more on human nature and the relations between the characters than anything else. There are some serious tearjerking moments in this game, and some moments that leave you pretty damn shocked. It's like nothing I've seen in a videogame before, and it could rival the most well written of movies. This is how you do 'cinematic' games right, without compromising any of the gameplay for it.  The gameplay's good, too, with really solid shooter mechanics and a pretty decent selection of weapons (really helps that you can dual wield almost any weapon, including shotguns and, yes, sniper rifles). My only gripe is that the later levels stop being conducive to stealth (which is viable in most of the game otherwise) and it starts to introduce a lot of frustrating bulletspongy enemies right before the end. I've seen much worse, though. I'd without hesitation call this game my favorite single player shooter ever.

The game is awesome. Killing nazis became kinda boring but New Order tries to refresh the concept with new ideas.  The 1940s is only an intro and the game starts off really in 1960s, when Germany has won and the allies have surendered. You're on a mission to kill Totenkopf, one of most prominent nazi in the world taken over by Nazi Germany. The atmosphere is dark, everything is taken over by Nazis, their propaganda is everywhere, and everyone whose not into tyranny is either opressed or killed.  I am truly amazed by the work they put in the voice acting. I'm a Pole and I truly hear Polish language with no false accent. I'm almost sure the German language is also spectacular and soldiers are not spewing off the false 'gibbery' German which I saw in many US productions such as Saving Private Ryan or Die Hard. Hats off, professionals were hired.  Also the notes and newspapers are in their native language, I can say the Polish ones are good. They add much to the game, as you learn about other parts of the world, what happened with USA, UK and so on. I like this kind of stuff. The weapons are great. They don't feel stiff or artificial. My one concern is only the pseudo Thompson that we get in the intro. Its fire rate surpasses all the weapons, even the modern ones. The modern times lack such fast firing weapon, not counting the detachable 'miniguns'. Creators of W:NO returned to the known 'pick up power ups, health and ammo' routine. While many players are used to modern solutions, where health regenerates over time and you automatically pick up ammo, this isn't such a bad idea. Old players will surely appreciate this, while other players will quickly get used to it. The story is engaging and will take us through the allied assault on Totenkopf's compound, psychiatric clinic, Berlin, London, and even the... let's just say it will have something to do with rockets. Enemies are not only soldiers but also robots, armored dogs, flying thingies very similar to manhacks from Half-Life 2, and of course various bosses. I won't hide that I really liked killing off nazi soldiers. And I really like you have the stealth option which works well. You don't have to go guns blazin', you can quietly kill the lieutenants that have the ability to call for reinforcements if alarmed. Overall this is a great game, wonderful FPS, but unfortunately, it is short. Well, can't wait to play the DLC.

I was incredibly surprised by this game. I expected mindless 90s style FPS, but got the best of early 2000s FPS with the addition of the good elements of newer games.  PROS: + Story is intriguing. (Stealth, Head-on, etc.) + Scavenging for those that want to; semi-regenerating health for those who don't care. + Many levels of difficullity. + Humor. + Graphics in cut scenes are breathtaking. It's rendered in-engine, but it doesn't look like it. + Nice to be able to shoot people without any moral qualms. The nazis here are complete monsters! + Interesting and scary antagonists. + No QTEs! + No Multiplayer! No launch-day DLCs! No 'AAA publisherisms' AFAICT!!!  CONS: - Still just an FPS, if you don't like those - A lot of collectibles. That audience wouldn't care less for 'Wolfenstein' ('what's that, lol?') as they already have a game(s) to play. This game is one of the best narrative FPS experiences since Half Life 2, and I don't say that lightly. I've been gaming, and playing FPS since the original Wolfenstein was brand new. As shooters evolved, they sort of reached their pinnacle as singler player storytelling experiences with Half Life 2. Graphics have gotten better, dialogue punchier, twists twistier, but there really haven't been many advancements in the decade since. I fact, we've seen a devolution into quick-time events, auto-aiming, simplistic cover mechanics, and a cookie cutter formula perfected via COD games.   THIS, however, is a refreshing turn to some of the virtues gaming has forgotten: leaning mechanics, punchy weapons, twisty, intelligent level design, and most of all, a storyline and gameplay progression intertwined in a way that improves both aspects. Like Half-Life, the world you play in expands and blooms into something fresh with every chapter. The key weapon here, a laser cannon, evolves in utility and power as you go along, just like the Gravity Gun of HL2. It even plays a key part in the final sequence, like that classic tool.  The point isn't to simply draw comparison to one of the most beloved games of all time, but merely to highlight just what this game does so RIGHT, that's often missing from other top tier shooters these days. There's no fat to trim, no boring side quests, no pointless morality scale, and no inventory system to juggle. This is straight up ballsy storytelling combined with rock solid shooter mechanics. I took about 14 hours to complete this and had far more fun in that time than other AAA games I've spent far more time with. Even better, I'm eager to start again, once I whittle my to-play list down a bit.

Just finished this game. Glad I bought it on sale.  SUMMARY: Awesome premise. Excellent style and aesthetic. Decent gameplay. Horrible script. Bad level design. The worst were the interstitial gopher missions clearly designed to stretch out the gameplay. Sadly, they had the opposite effect of, what I guess, were their other purpose; namely, help me get to know the characters. I did everything in my power to avoid slowing down the pace of the game by finding toys or welding torches carelessly thrown down sewers by my so-called friends.   Unfortunately, the real levels aren't much better. I was railed through so many interesting and atmospheric locations that I wish I could have explored and interacted with more fully. As it was, it just felt like I was checking boxes on the plot outline. Walked underwater a bit: Check. Shot a few globes to make stairs: Check. Push a button: Check. Fiddle around with some junk: Check. Watch a cutscene: Check. I guess I'm done with the secret underwater stockpile. Mazel tov. Next.   The game started out with promise but hit so many sour notes that I had checked out half way through. I found myself rushing through just to get to the end, skipping the increasingly eye-roll-inducing cutscenes, and telling the main character to shut his word hole and just get on with it. Seriously Blaskowicz, enough with the maudlin monologue. We get it.

I went into this with low expectations since it's one of the all to frequent 'reboots' of old series that seems to be happening these days, but it's actually a pretty damn good game.   The combat is fun, it doesn't bring many new new things to FPS really. You can lean out of cover to aim, and it lets you manually lean for those times the cover doesn't do it when you aim. You can also 'lean' down to prone and look under some doors to shoot out people feet, which is cool.   The graphics are really awesome in this game, and well optimized. I'm running pretty close to max on a 760 and had zero issues with framerate, although the graphics menu is pretty confusing, a bit of trial and error will be needed if you don't want to just use one of the presets. Cover/objects are destroyed by gunfire, enemies will lose arms, legs, heads, or even portions of their chest to expose ribs, depending on where you shoot them. Lasers can put holes through guys or even just explode them into soup.   I also quite liked the story. They made killing Nazis fun again, although making you hate Nazis isn't difficult, and had some good dialogue. It's hard to describe more without potential spoilers so I'm just going to leave it at that.  I got this full price (not on sale) and consider it money well spent.  9/9
