Highly recommend this game for FPS enthusiasts and also fans of Wolfenstein games.  Wolfenstein: The New Order took a while to grow on me. The prologue playthrough, whilst amazing graphics and initial new/fresh gameplay, started to get same-old pretty quickly. I initially only got about an hour in before parking it for other games. It didn't pique my interest enough to keep me hooked.  It wasn't until I went back to it about 6-12 months later that I realised that after about 2 hours playtime, the whole setting changes and the game really comes into it's own. The story is fantastic, with ample opportunity to send nazi scum back to whence they came from and there are some classic storyline moments that made me laugh. After several story plot moments, I was hooked and didn't stop playing until the game was completed. My only disappointment was the overall length of the game felt a bit too short. The pace of the story was breakneck speed and you wanted to keep slaying nazis but after killing a few bosses, that was it.  Overall though, it was a very enjoyable game and the storyline was intereting and humourous in parts. I highly recommend this game and I'm glad I persisted through the first hour or so to get to the real story. I look forward to playing the expansion.

Aside from three irritations (two moderate, one minor) with Wolfenstein: The New Order, the experience was great. Intense, enjoyable, and longer than expected. The story is a highlight--characters have depth and humor, and make you care more about the outcome than you would otherwise. Weapons are varied and behave realistically. Enemies are mostly smart. Harder difficulties are a challenge, though boss battles leave something to be desired.  The moderate irritations: A checkpoint save system (which is expected on a cross-platform game) that discourages creativity and taking chances, and the lack of a true stealth mode, even though remaining unseen and unheard is often crucial to staying alive. The minor irritation, which extends into 'Old Blood': BJ is captured too frequently and too easily, and there's no way to avoid it. It's just silly.

This game is awesome, good graphics, cool take downs, challenging gameplay, cool premise (even if the story is lacking), and surprisingly an immersive environment.   I got this game on sale for $10 which is why I feel it deserves a good review, if I paid full price I would have felt gypped because the replay value doesn't seem all that great. In the beginning you have to chose to save one of two people which has no real impact on the game just collectables you can find and that's pretty much it so it only really pays to play through it twice. anymore than that and it will become bland.   There are also no real memorable moments in the story, and the weapon wheel in this game was clearly not designed for a mouse and key board, I cannot begin to explain how infuriating it is to die just because how bad the switching of weapons is, you get a quick draw perk which makes you draw your weapon faster, but it doesn't matter because it still takes an eternity to get to it to the weapon you want to use on wheel.   Now to why I think this game is good, it's fun killing Nazi's, the guns are cool and have alternate firing modes which are all unique and fun to use. The death animations are cool, the gore is cool, nothing walking by a guy you killed and seeing his rib cage blown out or his head completely blown off. The trusty weapon you get is upgradable and the upgrades are scattered throughout the levels.   The alternate history is interesting and you find news articles scattered around which tell you what happened an X number of years ago. I would have prefered a different way of this story telling rather than the bland reading of random ♥♥♥ articles which you can easly over look.   The game also has some cool characters in it which I don't really feel like getting into.  Lastly, there is a level of the original Wolfenstein game called 'nightmare' which you play by sleeping on a matress. This was hilarious because you have your New World Order pistol with your New World Order hand gripping it but the rest of the level is in 16 bit.  In the end I give this game an 8/10

Played an beat Wolfenstein over a weekend while my girlfriend was away. I have to say, I wasn't expecting a great game, but I sure as hell got one. The graphics (while I've heard horror stories of performance issues) are very good. The character models and environments are top notch and very imaginative. You've got nazi pseudo-futuristic (considering it's ~1960) cities, a nazi moon base, a labor camp, Deathhead's castle and more. Not once did I get bored with a particular level. There's always something to do whether it be the standard run 'n gun, a puzzle, or exploring the hideout and talking to the many interesting NPC's.  I'm very surprised this game did not get as much media attention or praise because it's flat out awesome. I'll list some pros and cons instead of rambling:   PROS -Great narrative. Not once did the game's store feel boring or repetitive for me. -Interesting characters. BJ himself is a badass as always, but you've also got crazy nazi leaders, energetic comrades and a slew of well thought-out side character, of which my favorites were Klaus and J. -Ton's of great guns. You've got everything from the luger, to the shotgun, to the laser cutter which is really interesting and fun to use in puzzles (it harkens memories of HL2's gravity gun) -Varied environments. I already mentioned this in my opening. -Beautiful graphics. In some games you can compliment the character models or the texturing or the effects. Wolfenstien does all of them very well. I'm not sure if the cutscenes are keyframed or motion captured, but either way, they're real time and beautiful.  CONS -Somewhat short. I completed this over a weekend, but there's always 'The Old Blood' which is a prequel to this game's story. -Performance issues. I didn't have too much trouble running this on an AMD 7950 at close to max, provided I tweaked some settings, but I did see some very noticible slowdown. There are a couple settings that you can tweak to minimize this. If you have a beefy rig like I do now, you probably wont see any issues (I've tested the Old Blood on my new rig (i7, GTX 980ti) and saw no issues.    To sum it up, this game is definitely worth the money if you ever see it on sale, and I'll probably revisit it again soon to replay it, which isn't typical for most single player FPS's.  Buy it,

An excellent reboot of an old classic. BJ Blaskowicz is back and is all out of gum, probably because they don't sell it in a world where the nazis have won WWII. Something for everyone here; fans of the classic can enjoy a flashy, visceral shoot-em-up with zero moral quandaries and a plot that can be largely ignored as you murder your way from point A to point B. Those seeking a more nuanced experience can slow it down and immerse themselves in a well-realized post-war alternate reality with well designed backdrops, solid voice acting, a cast of interesting and occasionally amusing companions and a creepy, old-school, top notch villain. Someone at Bethesda gave a damn about teh quality of their produect here, and it shows. Give it a look, I promise you wont be disappointed.   Some of the things I enjoyed: 1) An engaging plot, with entertaining characters. Not precisely memorable, but very enjoyable. Aided by solid cinematic cutscenes that are well scripted/voice-acted, but concise enough that they dont detract from the pacing, nor break immersion through melodrama.  3) Split 'timelines' offer an ever-so-slightly different storyline for a second playthrough. If you're like me, you'll play the first timeline for plot, and the second for difficulty/guns-blazing/collectible completion while still enjoying a new perspective on the sequence of events. A clever way to extend the game's value.  2) Detailed environments (e.g.;pay close attention to the scenery in the asylum - every bit of blood or bullet hole tells a story). You're encouraged to explore this via the collectibles system - I highly recommend doing so. 3) Entertaining choice of run-n-gun or pseudo-stealth. The stealth mechanics are very rudimentary, but it's still a satisfying way to play occasionally. Given that BJ is nearly invincible at most difficulty levels, even if you play like a bloodthisty maniac, you never feel forced into stealth.  4) Entertaining weapons, satisfying playstyle. The shotgun was a little under-used due to, in my opinion, a slight bias towards remaining at range once in an allout firefight.   Cheers, Auracle

With the recent wave of rebooted franchises, this game could have been anywhere in the spectrum. The original was part of the initial wave of innovation that set the standard for FPS mechanics, and this one followed on the heels of the abomination that is the over saturation of the genre caused by CoD4: Modern Warfare.  And oh boy did this game ever deliver.  Wolfenstein: The New Order turned an old, rehashed genre into something fun and gripping to play. I got to run, gun, slide, knife, nade, and laser beam the ever loving crap out of the Nazi hordes, the true Wolfenstein experience.   What's that you say? I can sneak around as well? And it can have a meaningful impact on how I approach a level? Fantastic! I can just toss knives at some baddies, pop a few in the head with my silenced pistol, and then swing up with my dual wielded shotguns and blast this UberSoldat in the face until he kneels before my glorious American ♥♥♥.  Now you're telling me that there is a meaningful progression tree that requires you to explore all of the mechanics presented, without feeling overbearing and forcing you into a play style? Yes, please! Numerous secrets as well, with a useful menu that allows me to search for them without consulting a 3rd party guide. And, on top of everything, an interesting story that separates The New Order from its predecessors while still fulfilling that 'kill all the Nazis' itch. I honestly wasn't expecting anything in the story department, but it was quite solid. B.J. Blazkowicz is a bit more than your cliche massively muscled 'I'm going to rip your arms off and shove them down your throat' protagonist, but not by leaps and bounds. The story is more interesting than expected, but the focus is still firmly set on gunning down Nazis at all costs.  This game renewed my interest in First Person Shooters. I didn't expect there to be any kind of innovation, but The New Order came out as an interesting game with fun mechanics, a simple but engaging story, and good level design with multiple possible plans of attack. Not everything was perfect, though; the parts where you don't have access to a gun are confusing as the enemy will just casually walk at you with a baton and gladly get their faces beaten in when they see you. The giant Panzerhund parts are a huuuuuuuuuge pain in the butt, and almost every area where stealth can be extremely useful have something that forces you to brawl, most of the time including the elite level of enemies spawning. Overall though, the game was a joy to play. I give it a 9/10.

An exceptional first person shooter that blends old-school sensibilities with some of the quality-of-life improvements to be found in modern FPS. Classic FPS contrivances like expansive levels, hidden secrets and bits of armour (often looted from exploded Nazi robots) merge with contemporary touches, such as maps, objective markers and the ability to dual-wield basically every weapon in the game. Combine this heady mixture with incredibly satisfying gunplay that has just the right amount of recoil and extremely meaty sound effects, and you have some utterly fantastic arcadey gameplay. A real antidote to the 'bang, you're dead' twitch-gameplay of the modern military shooter.  The thing that really sold me on this game though was not the gameplay, excellent as it was, but the story. Yeah, I know. An old-school inspired shooter with a story. I was sceptical too, but this game just glows with the obvious TLC lavished on the writing; characters are all extremely likable and/or despicable as appropriate (this game made me hate Nazis even more than I did before, thanks Deathshead) and dialogue is believeable and often funny and touching. The relationships between characters feel genuine and it makes you care all that more.   B.J. especially was a revelation. When you think of characters like Doomguy or Blazkowicz, you think of the stereotypical meathead slaughter-machine. An empty vessel whose only purpose is to hold the gun and let you shoot the bad guy. But in The New Order, we see a B.J. Blazkowicz that is tired. He's seen enough death and cruelty to turn a man's soul sour, and you feel like the only thing keeping him going is the sense of moral outrage these Nazi scumbags provoke. He goes on because he must. Because of what he's seen happen to other human beings. And he gets to show a tender, even goofy and awkward side in his interactions with NPCs. I really didn't expect such a nuanced main character from a Wolfenstein game, but it's pretty amazing nonetheless.  I can't recommend this game enough. It's an awesome action shooter, full of pomp and bombast, that also knows how to add quiet moments and emotion for devastating effect. 9.5/10.

The New Order is one of the best fps’s released in the past few years mainly because of how satisfying and polished the gunplay is. The shooting packs a real punch, blowing limbs off nazis in a small hallway while dual wielding two automatic shotguns is a great feeling, the guns sound really powerful. The story is surprisingly pretty good for a Wolfenstein game, some cool characters and villains you love to hate and you can’t wait to kill. I really liked all the locations you visit, each level feels different from one another keeping the game from feeling boring or repetitive. It’s a great game overall it just doesn’t do anything really amazing to warrant me giving it a higher score it’s just a very fun fps.  8/10 (Great)

It could be better in many areas but overall it is a very fun romp. Played on hard difficulty and really enjoyed the experience as difficult as it was. The characters were hokey but lovably so. My biggest gripe is that there are a lot of inconsistencies - like in certain areas you can do something, let's say, jump a certain height. But later on, there are objects at that same height that you have no chance of jumping onto. When you're in the middle of a hard mode firefight, you don't want to be second-guessing what you can and can't do to escape.  If this is on sale for a reasonable price, it's worth it.

I remember Wolfenstein! What a game! Finished it with a pistol. Finished it on the hardest difficulty setting. Went for 100% secrets. Always stabbed dogs as they gave no ammo. Wolf3D was the FPS before FPS existed. I remember buying it on the SNES as well (was crap compared to PC)  Anyway, I had low expectations for this game but bought it on a steam sale. My expectations were un-merited. The story line is superb and highly emotive, I really felt like I gave a ♥♥♥♥ about my character and groups. Saved the young raw kid when he saved me from Robodog and then watched as he grew into the leader of the resistance. The play through for this game was short but I really enjoyed it. I felt the studio missed a trick by not allowing you maybe more open world missions from the Berlin head quaters but I guess it has to stick to its linear routes. The AI was interesting but a little unpredictable and I would have enjoyed more fire fights than just throw rockets / shotgun shells until it dies game play but that said they captured the orginal Wolf3D feel and made it relevent.  I loved the nods to the original as well, the sleep scene easter egg, the mecha boss and how the main character says 'Coming For You' just before the final boss fight. ( 'Coming For You' was what the mecha boss would say at the end of the game when you pulled him back in Wolf3D.) I really enjoyed my play though and would suggest it to anyone who likes FPS shooters in a sale. There is a certain joy about shot gunning Nazi's, blowing up Nazis and just basically destroying facist filth.  Good times. Good times.
